number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												This game is another shining diamond from Devolver Digital, makers of one of my all-time game series Hotline Miami.  (It even features some recycled Hotline Miami musik, so you know that part is wonderful.)A triumph for pixel art in games.Works off the principle that what goes up must come down (YES!--gravity), using this physic to create a whole new twist to twin-stick shooter arcade play.  Also, playing like a suicide-bomber can be to your advantage as you can use your plane to melee enemies as well as to fire missles.  Very challenging gameplay (the achievements will most likely not be hard to cook through, but the game itself provides a beautiful challenge and you can compete for high scores).The art is simplistic, but subdued, easy on the eyes, and beautiful.  The art style is unique and fun, the kind of art you would expect from Devolver.  Beige color-scheme is interesting.  Play-style is customizable (you can alter weapons/parts of the ship).The gravity mechanic doesn't make sense in light of the German war Aero-plane theme, but oh well.  It's a video game  and absurdity is welcome.  The sky and water serve as a function of the game, not just backdrop, so I guess it all works.I came to love this game in a very short time and this is definitely doing to be one of my top picks for a long while.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												LUFTRAUSERS is a delightful little game. The mechanics are remarkably simple, as well as the art style; but the overall package is incredibly fun. The best thing about the game to me is that it doesn't require much of the player. It is easy to jump in and out, but still make progress. The player is presented with attainable goals that are based on the modifications that are available and each modification is actually unique, which adds a great deal of variety to the game.All in all, LUFTRAUSERS is a ridiculously fun game. It is definitely worth a purchase.

												This is a frenetic, side-scrolling dog fighting game and it's a lot of fun!  The fact that it's a side-scroller means that simply allowing your plane to fall is a valid movement strategy.  You have unlimited ammo and your health will regenerate but you can only use one at a time.  Your health doesn't regenerate while you're shooting so you really need to balance your approach to attack and defense.

												I don't normally get into shmups, but this one is a lot of fun. The asteroids-style control scheme adds to the experience and the simple color palette lends a style that I find interesting.Playing the game you will unlock new parts for your plane and new graphical color palettes that can be changed out. It definitely doesn't feel like it is running at 60 FPS, which I think would be a much better experience for this type of game. Hopefully this is something that can eventually be addressed by the developer.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Awesome. But the game is very short even with it's high replayability. It's like that awesome dessert you get at French restaurant. It's super expensive, it's tiny, but when you get more you get super tired of it. So yes, Devolver digital is that artsy French patissier where they make super expensive, super tiny, but super satisfying items. (p.s. Which makes EA and UBI soft Chinese buffets as they are keep feeding something that you know it's generic. But since you are in a bandwagon that you have to just devour more and more of it :/)The game is about dogfighting. That's literally it. You can choose different style which aids the replayability of this game. But again, the stall mechanics provides insane movements and actions that you can perform, which makes this game very unique. However, get it when it's on sale for more than 50%. Five bucks or less for 2~3 hours isn't that bad. But for 10 bucks, there are better options. It's overpriced. But when you do get a chance to play it, do play. Because it's like no other games.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												As the embodiment of all things evil and War-like, I find this game a pleasure.You play as the pilot of some sort of Indestructo-Plane, able to regenerate lost parts, conjure a myriad of bullets, and dive-bomb into battleships with the force of a nuke.And even though the game gives you a single ship at the start, after a while, you are able to build your own monstrosity; e.g, a laser spewing, super-speedy, flying nuke which explodes upon death.You may not like the colour palet, but you can switch to different ones at a later point. My favourite is DISTINY.The soundtrack of the game is sublime, with the main theme changing with the different plane parts; That's really creative!If I had to say something bad about the game, it'd probably be SFMT Mode. It's insanely hard, but gives no reward other than more challenges. And while the on paper the Missiles are a fun idea, being able to drop homing missiles on your enemies, there almost usless as you can have only 4 at a time, and they do very little damage to anything other than cannon fodder.If you like fluent action, challenge and a wide variety of death-spewing ariel demons, then you'll not want to miss this!9/10 P.S; Love Trousers. I had to at some point...

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24
												If you appreciate building up skill in a game to eventually master it, this game very well may hook you.  The gameplay is a bit of luck and a lot of practice, with task and point based goals.  Shoot for a traditional high score using combos and brilliant maneuvers, or aim to kill harder and harder enemies up to the dreaded Blimp.The biggest calls this game has is its short round lengths, its high adrenaline, and that wonderful videogame feeling where you are an unstoppable boss until you mess up.If you like games where you face impossible odds, relying on a lot of practice, skill, and a little bit of luck, Luftrausers deliver well!

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												Sometimes when I play this game, I imagine the enemy saying this."Sir, we are pretty powerful, right?""What kind of question is that, Vladmir? Of course. We are unstoppable""Good to... Sir!"What, Vladmir!?""Look at this""What is it?""There is an enemy plane""It will be blown up soon. Wait for a minute""Sir, this plane has an underwater propeller and is firing missles. It also has a nuke for a body.""What? That is completely-" *explodes*In an industry full of games attempting to be stupidly serious, this is anything but. Where other games have cover, this has explosions. Where other games have story, this has customisable freakin planes.You can equip a body that fires missles out of it as you fire, giving the ability to recreate a one-man blitzkrieg where every enemy you see is basically screwed. Buy this game. Now.But in reality, I have really enjoyed this game. Like, I love it. It has it's downs, sure, but that's besides the point. It is fantasic to fly around in a full 360 degree angle and shoot anything that lives. I love it's customisation, it's charm, it's enemies, it's everything. I want you to buy it and see for yourself. Good luck out there, you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ pilot, you10/*explodes*

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												So, I'm just a few parts combinations away from full completion of this game, and wow. Just... wow.You start off in a pretty simple manner; you have a standard machine gun, normal armour, and an engine. Letting go of up stalls the engine, allowing you to begin drifting back to the water. Entering the clouds or the water causes you damage, to start with anyway. Stop firing, and any damage you took begins to regenerate. And that's the nice, simple start.By the end... Well, you'll be flying around furiously, firing giant fireballs that explode on impact with an enemy, equipped with a submarine propeller so water no longer hurts you, with the fuselage of a nuke that explodes on your death. Oh, and there'll be a siren going off, and not long after it's likely you'll be dead.And eventually, after some seriously difficult challenges... you'll unlock the U-Rauser, and boy, you probably didn't see that coming. But you'll have enjoyed every second.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												This is a great ARENA BASED shumup. Know before purchasing that the "missions" are challenges like "score 10k points" or "kill 3 submarines in one combo", they are NOT unique levels like you would find in Raiden or Gradius. This "one level" game is meant to be played over and over again; it's very difficult. Runs can be anywhere from 10 seconds to 10 minutes. You unlock parts as you go and after defeating a particularly large enemy, you unlock "hard mode". Good luck with that....Lots of unique ship combos with a different version of the Luftrausers original theme depending on what you pick. It's a really wonderful track, check it out on soundcloud if you haven't heard it. The controls are intentionally slippery but very well done. You aim your craft and then either thrust or stall, the challenge is cutting your thrust at the perfect time...weaving between the bullet hell and keeping your combo multipler at MAX. You unlock different color schemes as you progress, they're all pretty wacky.Luftrauser's arena loops like Defender, while the game controls like a bullet hell Asteroids. For $10 I recommend this game to fans of arcade shooters.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												Ok. Really and truly I want to give this game a thumbs up. Gameplay's solid , the combinations are nice and it's generally a very fun experience.But the names of some of the combinations in this thing kills it for me; and other people who'd happen to be in my shoes also. I know they're supposed to show the would-be awesomeness of the plane you're flying, but "Hellrauser" and "Fist of God"? Really? (I almost don't mind the "Karaterauser" and "Batman", albeit not by much.) Seriously, I don't see a real need to give the combos names proper to God alone/not to be profaned in one way or another. So please, change those names. You can come up with better titles than that.And I know there's a whole lot of you that disagree with me and will say "just don't use those." Again, it's not as simple as that. Once it's in the game, it can't be played. Of course the one thing I expect a whole bunch of you guys to say is "then don't play it then, it's just a game. Get over it" etc.But I needed to make that clear so that it could be possible for other people somewhere around my case CAN play this thing with a problem without boundaries being crossed and worst case scenarios befalling them. Like I said, I really wanna give this game a great score. I'd be recommending it if not for that.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Great arcade game. Fun flying and shooting mechanics, different combinations of weapons and ship part unlocks. Challenging game. Decent variety of enemies but expect to be getting very familiar with most. Quite hard gameplay but very addicting. Despite very simple controls the learning curve goes up steep for the first hour then flattens a little for a decent time as you get slightly better, completing challenges and unlocking parts (and colour schemes)...and then it explodes up again. Don't even bother with SFMT unless you are ninja at bullet hell. I really love the main game though, only game on my work computer, not that I get a chance to play it. Which is why I have it all my vitas too. Buy. Let go of fire to heal. The game microfreezes to when you get hit as an indicator.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												The most difficult game I have ever played. By far. Because it has the worst controls I have ever seen in a game in my life. No matter what, it is impossible to get used to the controls. I can't fly at all because the controls are so nightmarish. I don't care what anyone says, the controls are the worst in the history of video games. It gives me almost no real control over my plane. All I could do was fight gravity to stay out of the water but I just kept dipping down into the water. I can really only kill planes by unavoidably slamming into them. You have to stop firing to repair your plane but you still can't because the screen is filled every milimeter with bullets and planes that are impossible to avoid because you have no proper control over your plane. How this game got past their quality control team blows my mind. Obviously they have no QA department. Hopefully this gets taken down from the steam store and at least there's Hotline Hiami, which is pretty much the only great game that Devolver has made.0/10 horrible

												I love and hate this game at the same time, great gameplay, terrible balance/design, some strong enemies can oneshot you before you even know where they are (enemy ace, laser ace), all kind of unavoidable deaths, the rng is too strong about how and which enemies will spawn. Will update this review if they update the game which is a lot of fun but very unfair/unbalancedFeatures needed:Proper balancing (who the hell uses missiles)Warnings about in which direction enemies (the strong ones at least) are (like how Paladins warns you about bombs)Altitude meterVision of yourself while underwaterMaybe something to tell you which direction you are aiming, sometimes you don't know where you are going because of all the chaosAn encyclopedia of parts (more information about them) and enemies (like spelunky)Not a must have but would be nice anyway:Write combination name to instantly pick those parts (example: Kamikaze=original+nuke+superboost) (like dota heroes) List of favorited combinationsWorth buying if it's at 75% discount

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												So I've now logged over 40 hours of play and I feel its time to update my review. I can now recommend this game BUT only for the game play and the controls, which are so solid that when you die you know its your fault. I say "when" because this is a bullet hell side scrolling sh'mup and you are going to die. This one is a challenge, again, I'm at 40 hours and I'm still 3 missions away from 100% completion. *sigh* There are still bits to this game that I find upsetting. Normally I would care less, but the game is soooo good that the little things to it are upsetting. ConsBeing color blind, I found that I can only use 4 of the 15 color schemes. The other 11 color schemes, I'm lost. Majority are horrendous anyways. I still find the 4:3 game play a huge disapiontment. I would really love to know the reason Vlambeer decided to go with this format.Still get lost navigating the menu... Yeah after 40 hours of game play. Calibrations! The controls are just too damn sensative in the menu and seem to be inconsistent at times. Controls just stop working.Aiming is still very difficult due to a number of factors. First, for weapons the have low frequence of shots, you have to guess when you are able to shoot again. Example missiles, you can only shoot 4 at a time. Sometimes they go rogue on you preventing you from firing. This is problem for health regen., keeping up your combo, defense, and offence. Second, the lower bit graphics also contribute.ProsEverything else. Final ThoughtTo put it simply, its a great game with the worst design. [Prior Review]+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+There is something I'd like to note before I review. I do play this game regularly in hopes that some of these issues are fixed. This review and rating may be updated.I love this game, which has some of the finest shmup action I've played. Beside the game play and the audio, for me, nothing else works. First off, I don't understand the decision the developer made with color scheme, more modes, more horrendous than the next can be unlocked to making it even more difficult than the last to identify enemies. A characteristic of this game that seems like a truely unnessisary hinderence. I'm really hoping there is a normal color scheme mode to unlock. Additionally, when you first load the game, you get the splash screen in wide screen, then in the game, standard. Black strips? What a tease, I can look past this small issue, only if it wasn't used a method to limit the firing range of the player and not the computer. Also with the graphics, I don't mind they are low res but it makes for difficult aiming without a line of sight or some other targeting method to see where you are shooting, this is critical when using weapons with a low frequency rate of fire. Next, navigating the menu's are a chore and shouldn't have to be. When you have 'go to' screens set to buttons that change on you pending the menu screen you are looking at can get confusing. The menu settings can be changed way too easily and inadvertantly as the controls are too sensative with no way to turn them down or even have dead zones. And how the heck do you exit the game? Well, took me a couple games to firgure out but you have to navigate to one screen to exit the game or even get to the options, that screen being what I thought was the start of the game. There really isn't too much more to this game and these intended unnessisary problems really do break my heart as I'm seeing a great game go bad. but If you are the type of gamer that can look past these problems, I do recommend this, but otherwise as it stands today, I can not. Maximum I'd give this a 6/10. That 6 easily could be a 9 or 10. Will update if game does. -RoX

content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												There are better dogfighting simulators avialble for free, there are better arena shooters for free.  I will provide examples if pressured.If you think the unique mechanics of this game itself make it worth purchasing, then the eb version is free and feels better to play, though it is still not very entertaining.The special part of this version of the game is that completing a number of missions will unlock new ship parts and extras like cutscenes and background color swaps.  The ship parts are all given strengths and weknesses, but they are poorly balanced to be overpowered or useless.  I will provide examples if asked.The missions themselves do not directly relate to being "good at the game", and one can quickly earn all ship parts and a randomizer but save for the last three without beating the game once (It took me around four hours).  The music is made up of a universal part and three parts that are assigned to each part of your ship-- in other words the music has a very large chance of being disjointed and offputting, not around long enough to stick in your head, and , worst of all, gimmicky.  If you play with the randoms on so that you have a chance to ue some of the useless parts instead of playing with the superior build.The extra backgrounds are likely to be offputting save for one or two, based off of your color preferences, and even the faded black/white (beige) film aesthetic seems tired and uninspiring.  The main and common grunts are too easy to take care of, and only pose a threat when they are in groups of more than ten, and the large battleships are too powerful.  Once you learn how to fight the battleships, then you are able to survive until the enemy dogfighters arrive--- which are actually fun to fight instead of annoyances like the blades of grass that are the grunts or the trees that are the battleships.Though, to even have fun DOGFIGHTING IN A DOGFIGHTING SIMULATOR, you have to make it through the boring first section,which happens to be very long.  Then, while you are polishing your skills, the boss will show up, leaving no time to enjoy yourself.--To be continued--

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
A very addicting arcade shooter with insane acrobatic maneuvers


YouTube™ Video: Luftrausers || Indie Arcade Action Shooter [PC] 

			Views: 27		

			A very addicting arcade shooter with insane acrobatic maneuvers + Great background music / sounds + Unique very addictiong mechanics (you can spin and change direction to dodge bullets while gravity...		

+ Nice background music that fits very well with the game+ Unique very addictiong mechanics (you can spin and change direction to dodge bullets while gravity is constantly pulling you down, however you must stop shooting for your health to regenerate, so it's a mix of dodging while trying to find time to shoot)+ A variety of different weapons, engines, and body parts that create a different experience each time + Challenges (which you need to complete to unlock more parts) are similar to achievements, and make you play differently each time depending on the challenge. (like kill 5 boats)+ The Airship boss is pretty awesome and takes some time to figure out how to defeat it.- There's no health bar, so it can be hard to tell when you are about to die. Basically a circle appears around your plane when you are close to death.- The Difficulty can feel a bit unfair at times, it's randomly generated so some playthroughs are easier than others.- There's really only 1 level in the game, so I feel like it's lacking content / repetitive- The Screen-Space is quite limited making it hard to see where enemies are

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												LUFTRAUSERS (yes, it's actually allcaps) is an arcade-esque bullet hell shooter in which you are a RAUSER, aka, a plane 'ace', as it were. As a RAUSER pilot, it is your job to protect the Fatherland with glorious engineering bestowed by... blowing up♥♥♥♥♥♥LUFTRAUSERS has fun, addictive gameplay, and retraux graphics that somehow manage to be more detailed than a lot of other games relying on the same art style. Sparks fly from your plane, smoke billows from damaged enemies, and explosions shake the screen like you've had too much coffee. The overall feel of playing is seriously engaging, as every shot you take and every movement you make feels... just fantastic. For every major accomplishment (such as, say, blowing up your first battleship) you get a short little cutscene celebrating your accomplishment, making you feel genuinely proud of your amazing skill.Upgrades are unlocked fairly frequently, but the real challenge is unlocking the final three mystery parts. Trust me, that♥♥♥♥♥♥is worth it, and don't spoil it for yourself.For those of you who truly find joy in pain, there's also an unlockable SFMT mode, in which the game takes it up to 11... and breaks the scale. Good luck surviving that.In short, LUFTRAUSERS is a seriously engaging, pew-pew explosions, defend our engineering and take down hordes of enemies with this plane, simulator. Worth it at base price, must-buy on sale.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												LUFTRAUSERS, a game as whole as it's own trailer entails it to be, not much more but perhaps less then one would expect from a 10 dollar game on steam. I have not played the Flash version of this game, but after playing, what is in my opinion, an overpriced flash game. Here are a few reasons why:Controls:It is easy to tell from a mile this game was made for a gamepad, as none of the menu screens have mouse control, and more often than not end up taking you where you did not want to go in the first place. An example would be trying to costimize the Rauser, getting to the Hanger is as easy as pressing right with the arrow keys or D-pad, but instinctively would immidiately start trying to optimize the desired prefrence for the craft. Instead have to confirm what you want to customize the plane, a simple rotation selection screen, then have to press X to set the plane as complete. Key-binding is awful, a set track of trying to understand what you want to bind to makes for a frustrating adventure, where a simple sheet simply saying what key is for what button would have made this game worlds better. On top of ths, it appears I cannot find the file that contains the text file to easily bind what I want to which key.In game flying feels unnatural as well. Accurately aiming the Rauser in one direction is harder than it sounds and is pure frustration when this game could do with precise free aim instead of this "single stick control". More often than not I turn in to Kamikaze dolphine that wasn't build for the water. Being shot by things off screen does not help either....Graphics:Sepia pixlated style. Again, something that the trailer covers, but, this makes certain  projectiles, such as the lazer, disappear behind clouds, and the beam is the exact same collor, shade and tone of certain things with the background. The amount of things on screen feels alittle empy. As I said, being shot off screen is a real pain, with no indicator of where the enemy is after the shots have travelled far off and more accurately that the hopeless Rauser that sprays blindly in to the distance hoping to get a kill, percpetively wishing that you had the same sight range as your enemy AI, BUT MOST CERTAINLY DON'T. This is what makes me feels extremely cheated when playing this game.Sound:Music? Exellent. A bit overpowering at max volume (ingame settings) but good. That is, one track slightly moddified with your craft's load out. Other game sounds? intentionally styleized with the look, but nothing outstanding. Could easily be replaced with someone making "pew pew" and weird lazer noiced with their mouth and it'd be the same._____For something that started simple, it sure as hell stayed that way to be pushed out with a price tag on it. There are many games that follow similar pixle art style and are easily better than this. This is a game that could have had LOADS of more content for what we pay for, but sadly not worth the 10 dollar tag this game asks for.Could easily be better.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												Luftrausers is a game where you engage fighter planes over sea. Made by Devolver Digital and Vlambeer, it has a delicious arcade feel to it, meaning it can be played for 5 mins or 5 hrs, depending on the mood you may be in. Multiple enemy types to destroy, many leaving the player with a great feeling of satisfaction (I'm looking at you, battleships and blimps).There are lots of different parts available to the player for the customization of their rauser. There are also many unlockable color palettes to choose from, which allow you to change up the flavor of your rausing here and there. The difficulty is perfectly scaling, increasing a little more with each kill, each passing second of your continued survival. The one big drawback I've found with this game is no multiplayer option. Even a local VS mode would help add so much more variety to this already immensly addicting game. If you like techo/electro music with a sort of diesel influence, you will love the soundtrack of Luftrausers. It has a great selection of tracks which perfectly match up to the setting of your aireal combat. If you are looking for a mobile-esque timesink, look no further than LUFTRAUSERS!9/10 needs moar firepower

												The fighting mechanics are unique but not in a good way, they are too clunky and make it very difficult and frustrating to try to kill ships. All rounds are mostly the same, the only drive is to try to kill as many enemies as possible before you die to unlock parts,  and it does not feel like your skill really matters in the outcome. There are no really interesting fights, badass bosses or in general some unexpected events to break the monotony, it's just the same brainless planes and ships that only have different degrees of hp and bullets. Just saying, for less money you can buy metal slug 3 which has much more content and much more interesting enemies, badass bosses, fluid mechanics, secrets, multiplayer ecc. All in all not much to say about this game, I did not find it particularly fun, and it's definitely not worth 9 euros.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2016
												LUFTRAUSERS (the title is, apparently, all caps) is a very simple 2D arcade-style game. You control a plane which flies around and shoots enemy planes. Unlike a schmup, where you proceed left-to-right or top-to-bottom, this is a side view, looking at a plane flying over an ocean, dogfighting vertically and firing on boats below.The game has a highly non-standard control scheme – you can fire, you can boost, and you can pitch your plane up and down, in a full 360 degree circle. The controls are very simple and kind of unusual, but you get the hang of them after a while.The game has 8 different enemy types – basic planes, a nastier kind of plane, giant blimps, basic boats, submarines, battleships, and two rare enemy types which almost never spawn. You will encounter them all in fairly short order, and at that point, you’ve seen all that the game really has to offer – there is an alternate mode which is basically a bullet hell mode, but even the regular mode can start bordering on that at times.You can customize your plane with five different weapons, five different bodies, and five different engines, each of which alter the gameplay of the game in reasonably significant ways, but ultimately the variety granted by these unlockable parts wears off after a short while. There are in-game missions which allow you to unlock parts and color schemes, each of which is attached to one of the parts, with each part having six such missions attached to it. If you beat all the missions, you unlock a final, alternate plane.Really, this game is decent enough gameplay wise, but it just doesn’t have much depth to it. It is really simple and there just isn’t much variety to it in the end, so you’re likely to get bored with it after a short time.If you got it as part of a bundle or something, it might be worth looking at, but it just isn’t worth buying – it just feels too simple to feel like an adequate stand-alone game.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
$2 Flash Game with a $10 Pricetag$10 for this?! Are you for real?! Got this at 75% off and I'm still not sure I got the money's worth... it literally plays like a free flash game you find online.-The game is fun for the first ten minutes but it gets repetitive very fast. You see all of what this game has to offer pretty quickly. The lack of enemy variety doesn't help. There's no motivation to continue playing except for the objectives on the plane pieces; 90% of which are easy as all f*ck and the other 10% are basically impossible without blind luck (Oh hey, that rhymed). If you're an achievement hunter that's into some mental masochism- here's your new kink-The only thing this game really has going for it is trying out differen't airplane combinations. I won't lie, it is fun seeing/playing the different combinations and reading the unique names for each one... but that whole experience is quickly sullied when you find out how repetitive it still ends up being. Thinking up some clever/funny names does not justify a $10 pricetag to me. Most of the combinations really don't change the gameplay at all either (only two that I can think of that really do any major gameplay changes the Melee body and the Underwater engine). Any other piece than those and you'll be flailing in the air firing aimlessly. -People are saying the controls are really tight- but I found them to be quite loose and floaty. Maybe because I used a controller? It hindered the gameplay signifigantly. It's nearly impossible to react to split-second situations... which is all this game is (a bullet hell of split-second situations). You'll be spending a majority of the time shooting frantically, not tactically. That's not to say you won't be shooting tactically (good luck taking down a battleship otherwise) it's just most of the time you'll be spamming your shots in a general direction hoping to hit something as opposed to actually aiming to hit something. I know, that's a factor in most (if not all) bullet hell/arcade shooter games like this, but it just seems way more apparent in this one. That it's entirely Luck > Skill. Dying every 2mins, just to respawn at the exact same point everytime, with the same slow start up everytime.... it gets monotonous fast. The controls could of helped that, but they don't. Least not with a controller.-Good luck if you wanna try rebinding keys. Misunderstanding the (easily misunderstandable) menu can get you to a point of being forced to manually find and delete an innocuous file in your /%APPDATA% folder... just to return the controls to the default settings... instead of a simple "Reset to default" in the options menu. Don't believe me? Go to the community hub and read the first Q&A on the FAQ. It's that much of a problem. I'd be willing to gamble that there's a recent post there with someone complaining and/or having trouble with the key bindings right now if you went and checked. The store page says "Full Controller Support"... as far as I'm concerned, that's a lie-The "cutscenes" are a joke. Literally just flashes one picture when you kill one of the (7 or 8) different enemies for the first time...  I know it's an arcade game and all, but damn, why even bother if it's gonna be that terrible. Almost seems like a slap in the face after a certain point.-To top everything off you get a pretty ugly/stale looking theme and a lot of the other themes you unlock (the other only real attraction to this game (unless you're a closet nazi or something)) are either buggy or just hinder most situations by making enemies harder to see.If you're looking for a small, "pass the time" type of game just to blow a quick 10-15 minutes... I'd still say you can spend the time better beatin' off. Or, if you're tired from all that jerkin', you're still better off buying something like 'Bit Blaster' for 99c. 1/10th the price but 10x the fun. Ironic, too, because that game lists this one as one of the developers inspirationstldr -  This game is way overpriced for what it offers. If you really are sold about getting this then wait until it's on sale 75% off or more, or you'll probably regret it.

content:
Posted: January 2
												In a 9.0 review in EGM from 2014, Luftrausers is described in this way: "Hearkening back to a bygone era of simple-yet-deep arcade games where you played for score, not story, Luftrausers takes basic ideas in concept and execution and turns them into hours of challenging, chaotic fun."I agree with all the above, so you can stop there if you wish. Indeed, in Luftrausers, you get to make your grandfather proud, who served in an Unspecified War on an Unspecified Side as a decorated kamikaze fighter and managed to fly experimental laser-based *cough cough* Luftwaffe aircraft in the nostalgic era of Unspecified global conflict that spawned such innocent things as Popeye and nuclear fission and resulted in that same grandfather hiding in Rio de Janero for a few decades to conceive your mom and maybe eventually you too. It is a game that depicts acts of aerial valor and ultimate sacrifice on the wings of physically impossible aircraft diving in and out of the water to kill a lot of people for fun and high scores.I'm not trying to act surprised that this game called Luftrausers is what it is. It's supposedly funny, but I don't really get the jokes. If I throw on a fedora and crack a whip and punch the makers of the game in the face, I'll also go on record saying their game "belongs in a museum!" but specifically in the museum of Things A Lot of White People Thought Were Good Ideas, alongside a collective self-assurance that Resident Evil 5 is not racist or colonialist in any fashion, despite a macho government agent stomping through the Congo to accidentally shoot a whole bunch of dark people in the face for being diseased. I mean, as we all know, Starship Troopers is just an awesome stupid action movie about beautiful people fighting a good fight.I honestly don't get it and you are free to try to explain to me where all the elusive self awareness or ironies lie in the game. What are we supposed to make of this alternate reality version of Joust from Man-in-the-High-Castle America? What's the point of going after these aesthetics? Is the music that evokes the sound of countless oiled black boots marching only a "gentle nod" to a movement that murdered millions of people? Some idiot thinker coined the phrase "all's fair in love and war" and Luftrausers is low-key cool with donning a crisp SS uniform if there's savage arcade action to be had with an inbound bass drop. How quickly Dieselpunk gives way to Nazi-punk! If you pitched this game to me, I'd say it sounds fun. If you then showed me your private box of concept art next to pop-pop's secret insignias, I'd stop letting you out of my line of sight, expecting you to turn your feckless eyes on me to ask if I actually believe the Holocaust happened as some kind of secret handshake you expect me to accept.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												LUFTRAUSERS is addicting, let me start by saying that. You customize your plane, take to the sky, and have some bullethell fun.When I say it's addicting though, I don't mean it in a good way. It's addicting like heroin or crack cocaine is addicting, at it's core the game is barely playable.The game mechanics are fine, really, they are, you fly around in a way that no pilot should never ever have to fly (i.e. cutting the engine off to make a hard turn, spinning in circles just to engage at the last second before hitting the water), shoot at boats and planes, and later, shoot at dirigibles and submarines. Let me start with that first one: I saw one review of this game that described the game's controls as "flawless." This is in no way the case since it feels like someone took a bullet hell, stapled that vector graphic Tank battling game to it and called it a day. In no way should anyone have to control like this in a bullet hell.As I mentioned before, you can customize your plane, and this is neat. But this is where the game falters THE MOST. Most of the unlockable parts you, well, unlock, are absolutely useless. You can unlock a melee fighter body which can ram into thinks without even getting a scratch, but when you realize that this is a bullet hell you should be uninstalling the game. You can also unlock a few other bodies, but all of them are ♥♥♥♥ing useless with the exception maybe one or two. All of the other bodies basically cripple your plane in the hopes that you'll find the tactic fun or interesting. The weapons I don't really have a problem with. They all have their ups and downs with the exception of missile, which no sane human being would ever use, but for the most part they feel finished and polished. It's such a shame the dev didnt take the time to ♥♥♥♥ing do the same for the other parts you can apply to your plane.And then there's the amount of parts you can have. The game's store page boasts 125 combos to add to your plane, but when you factor in the undeniable truth that most of the bodies and engines are ♥♥♥♥ing useless, you're instead left with about 50 useful combinations. And, while 125 may seem like a lot of parts, YOU WILL UNLOCK THESE PARTS WITHIN AN HOUR, POSSIBLE EVEN LESS. THAT'S RIGHT, ALL OF THE PARTS WITHIN AN HOUR. I.E., THE BIG GOAL  OF THE GAME, IS ACHIEVABLE IN AN HOUR OR LESS. If they don't expand on the part customization section of the game, or at least improve what you get, I see no reason to even touch this game.Also, you get to unlock color schemes for completing the entirety of a challenge tree. They're eyesores. And the names of these color schemes are the devs' names backwards. ♥♥♥♥ING. CLEVER.The game's prequel was a flash game called LUFTRAUSER. With the tacked on S, it makes sense that this is not the only ♥♥♥♥ing thing that's tacked on. Don't buy this game.

Posted: April 6, 2014
												First of all, I use a Xbox 360 Wireless controller w/ Wireless Reciever while playing this.  This fast paced, smooth thumb stick controlled game is the sort of game I would've loved to have spent quarters on as a kid at the arcade. Posted: April 7, 2014
What is it, and what's so good about it?Crunchy. Fast. Addicting. Simple.Much of the praise that you can attribute to Nuclear Throne is present in this arcade-style Vlambeer title, in which you play the role of a fighter pilot who flies a highly customizable jet. However! You fight a battle against insurmountable odds. A battle where your loss is inevitable. The question is, just how long can you last? How high of a score can you accrue?Every game begins relatively the same, with you launching out of a submarine and having to destroy some enemy fighter pilots who fly slow and fire ocassionally. Then, you'll see some boats who'll shoot in bursts of three. Before long, your screen will be full of barrages of anti-air flak coming from battleships and streams of machine gun shots stemming from ace-fighters. Once in a blue moon you'll see space-ships with lasers and if you're good enough to kill enough enemies you'll be having to deal with a Zeppelin overhead which serves as the boss of the game. Each enemy you kill moves the difficulty up a little bit, meaning there isn't difficulty spikes per se...it's really a gradual thing. Hardmode (called SFMT) just cranks it to the max off of the bat and makes the playing field more even (read as advantagous) for the AI.The controls boil down to the arrow keys and "x" to fire. Left and right are to turn your plane, while up is to accelerate in the direction you are facing. What's rather cool about Luftrausers is gravity. If you don't accelerate, you'll fall down to the water below and take damage over time for being submerged. Holding down x will allow you to fire indefinitely, but won't allow you to heal (which only happens when you aren't firing, thus potentially jeopordizing your combo). Your down arrow is only used for menus. This control set-up and gameplay style is remarkably simple, and equally so effective. Meaning keyboard users will find their frustration not in controlling the game, but rather from getting destroyed in SFMT mode like everybody else.And the music, just superb. The game only utilizes one "song" but drastically alters what it sounds like depending on what parts you use on your plane. I forget which part (weapon, body, propulsion) changes what instrument (riff, bass, percussion) but it does and it makes each combination sound rather unique. The crescendo of the song, which remains the same regardless of loadout, is perfect for divebombing a pesky battleship while your own aircraft is ablaze and getting out of there.To unlock parts and different colour schemes, you need to complete challenges. Like "kill x number of fighters with this part" , "get x amount of points" and what have you. Most are quite acheivable, some laughably so and others quite bloody aggravating.What of the bad?Despite all the customization you can do, there are some combinations that are just infinitely more effective than others. To the point where you'll just want to stick to a select few load-outs. For me, I found that builds that combined speed with constant fire (the laser in particular for it's combo-friendly nature) simply worked the best. To the point where you are able to survive indefinitely by speeding horizontally near water-level and avoiding higher altitudes and major vertical deviation.Some enemies rarely show up, namely the submarines (which have a microscopic chance to spawn when fighter-aces do) and the "secret enemies" (a fighter equipped with lasers and a sub with machine guns, also both tied to fighter-ace spawns). This wouldn't be much of a problem if some challenges weren't tied to killing 'em or killing 'em while at max combo. I've also noted that some challenges seem a tad broken, as the game sometimes doesn't track your killstreaks properly (kill x enemies while firing non-stop or without firing at all) despite the combo meter indicating the correct number.And apparently there is some clear-save glitch out there that others have encountered. I don't know how it happens and I fortunately have not stumbled upon it.So in conclusion...Luftrausers is an enjoyable, sometimes frustrating experience that'll burn a number of hours away and have you hungering for that high-score. Its visuals contain a good amount of character, its audio is crafty and any Time Pilot fans out there will probably christen it as the spiritual sequel also on steroids. If you are looking for "story", "levels" or "dialogue", you won't be getting it here. This is an arcade experience and not-so-serious flying sim, not a bloody fairy tale. Though in my head-canon, the main character is a future clone of the Red Baron fighting for control of the Principality of Sealand against an exaggerated Sealandic defense force in the year 1978Verdict9 USD worth of quarters hidden in the cockpit of a fighter plane out of 1 set of push-ups performed in a RAF training facility.

Posted: November 3, 2015
												This is where I wish Steam had some sort of "middle ground" for reviews, as it really does pain me to give this the ol' thumbs down.  However, I can't say I'd recommend the game as an overall experience at $10, despite all that it does oh-so-right.As many others have said, the game controls great, and it really is a lot of fun zipping around and shooting stuff.  The problem is that aside from the various part-specific objectives to complete, there isn't any progression when it comes to the actual game.  You pick your parts, head into combat, fight the same random assortment of the same seven or so enemies, eventually die, then repeat.  There aren't any other levels or anything, so the game ends up feeling more like a proof of concept for a much grander concept.  I saw all the enemy types in the game within about half an hour, unlocked all the plane parts before the two hour mark, and got tired of attempting the remaining objectives soon after.Still, it was really fun and unique before I hit the "this game's really not going to throw anything else new at me, is it?" point.  While "leave them wanting more" might work to some degree, I shouldn't be wanting as much more as I am out of Luftrausers.

Posted: November 9, 2015
												Luftrausers is a superficially simple, but perfectly tuned dogfighting game. Before your inevitable death, you dodge, weave and stall around the enemy hordes in your custom superplane, trying to take out as many of them as you can before the end comes. Every death brings the promise of higher rankings, and more unlocked options for your craft, each with their own challenges.Something like an even more arcadey version of the old Amiga game Jetstrike!.As with all Vlambeer titles, it's also terribly hard, especially in the later stages of challenges (I'll probably never unlock everything), but the design is perfect, down to the music (which remixes for every possible custom craft!).

Posted: June 10, 2014
												This game does three things I really like in games:1) A controlled physics sandbox2) Item synergy and emergent gameplay3) Multiple layers of depthLuftrausers is an extension of the flash game Luftrauser, which I played a ton. The first thing you'll notice is the striking visual style; not only is the sepia tone unique but also the way it blends shading and very low resolution rendering to create something that looks like pixels but has the feel and versatility of polygons. There are a ton of bullets on screen at once, defeated enemies blow up into bits, which then make splashes on the water, which by the way shows reflections. It's gorgeous.I guess the major gameplay mechanic is the jet system, which actually incentivizes not being held down constantly as without it you can turn on a dime. When you combine that with a gravity mechanic you get a really interesting physics sandbox of sorts. The other major mechanic is how you fire and heal; it again incentivizes not holding down a button constantly because you only auto-heal when you're not firing. Altogether these form a bullet hell unlike you've ever played before, with different strategies used for enemies below, above, and amongst you.What really sells it though is the upgrade system, you get different parts that you can mix and match and are very tangible, with a lot of weight given to their respective properties. This is where it's really emergent, as you can try new possibilities to test how the physics or other elements will respond. Yeah there are bad combos, but that only makes the great ones that much more special. There are even specific challenges curated for each and every part; it feels like a lot of thought went into each one. Also great is there's a lot of layers to the experience: at the beginning you'll play just to get a hang of manuvering about, and then you'll start trying to take out various enemies, like ships. All the while you'll be ranking up, which you can max out even if you're bad at the game. But then you're going to start unlocking ship parts, and testing each of those out. And then you're going to try to take out a blimp (which btw the first time is the most wtf moment, right?). And then there are missions to complete, and if you're old-fashioned you can always go for high score. There's a lot of content for such a single faceted game. My one complaint with the game does lie here, however, as I feel the difficulty spike after you unlock SFMT and start focusing on missions is a bit much and actually caused me to stop playing a game I would otherwise love to 100%, as there was just too little reward in the last half and probably too much in the first.

Posted: May 26, 2014
												When LUFTRAUSERS goes, it really GOES. Your fighter aircraft launches into the air. Give it a second or two, and a horde of smaller planes start chasing it. Battleships fire at you from below. And then larger planes start bringing down the pressure before a blimp threatens to obliterate you (that is, if you haven’t been obliterated already).Your challenge is to survive the frenetic action and take down these vessels as you weave through the enemy fire. The balancing act of returning fire and then letting off to allow your fighter reprieve to heal up is core to your gameplay.Experimenting with the different combinations of craft parts, completing missions and racking up higher and higher scores is all part of the fun here. LUFTRAUSERS is THE modern bullet hell-esque / arcade shooter game.

Posted: June 23, 2014
												Although LUFTRAUSERS is not a SHMUP in the traditional sense, I'm still gonna call it 'SHMUP ON DRUG' due to it's bullet hell and thre adrenaline rush.The gameplay is simple yet clever and addictive. You try to stay alive using customizable parts to suit your own play style. The 'stop-shooting-to-regenerate-health' mechanic keeps you focus on the most important part, KILL and STAY ALIVE, rather than putting you in difficult situations where you died just because you need to grab 'that healing item'The control is very responsive, although a bit confusing at first (if you're used to the six/eight axis free movement implemented in modern games), in LUFTRUASERS, you use LEFT/RIGHT to pivot/rotate your plane and UP to use the throttle/forward, but once you get used to it (and learned to master the control for the part combination you of your choice), you'll be going for the kill!AWESOME MUSICS

Posted: May 19, 2014
												I remember the first time I ever played this when it was still just a flash game. It was an OK game at best... just another typical arcade shooter adapted for use with web browsers. It certainly wasn't my favorite. The design seemed minimalist and the gameplay was not very satisfying, and the controls had quite a learning curve.Then, I saw this on Steam... and I thought, "Why the hell not?"Honestly, that was a solid decision.Upon playing Luftrausers again, I felt an odd satisfaction in the way that the game had changed. The visuals were improved, albeit with the same graphical style, which really did feel pretty nice. I noticed also the in-game menus that the previous version lacked as well. When I launched my rauser for the first time, I struggled a bit with the controls but after a few tries I felt very maneuverable. The increased enemies and enemy variety made the game interesting enough to play.Upon returning to the hangar after a few unsuccessful missions, I found customizing my rauser and testing it out to be quite entertaining. I put together something that I thought would compliment my play style and I was not disappointed. After unlocking more parts, I prioritized experimenting to find a good combination. Needless to say, having the customization option that the prequel lacked is enthralling.Between the updated graphics, the customization, and the unique enemies, I would say that this is one of the best arcade games I have ever played. The amount of satisfaction is overwhelming. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys arcade-style shooters. I will be having lots of fun with this game in the near future.

Posted: May 13, 2014
												What a satisfying little title, before this I cant remember the last time a high score meant any thing to me. The concept is simple and would feel more repetitive if it werent for the multitude of combinations in aircraft style. Controls feel as fluid as you can get in a game, every action on screen is either because you meant it or you made a mistake. The simple art style and music just tie everything up nicely. Dont expect to play this game for hundreds of hours (aint nobody got time for that shizz anyway) but its an awesome experience while it lasts.

Posted: April 22, 2014
												This game is just pure fun. It's very simple - all you do is fly around and shoot things - but it's the way it feels that makes it so much fun to play and almost impossible to put down. It has that one-more-round phenomenon going on.It's kind of a game that has to be experienced to fully get why it's so great, but watching some videos should give you a good impression. The planes are incredibly responsive and every weapon is super fun to use. There's a ton of unlockable plane parts too, which all make huge changes to how you might choose to approach the game. This, together with the different Achievement style missions attached to each part, gives the game a hell of a replay value.Visuals and music are also amazing. The minimalistic look makes it easy to see what's going on even when there's a million planes and bullets on the screen. The music is amazing and it changes dynamically (based on your plane I think?) so you'll never get tired of it.You might only end up playing Luftrausers for a few hours but they'll be some amazing hours.

												Look past the black bars either side of your screen, cumbersome menus and a framerate locked at 30 and you'll find a bona fide modern throwback on the level of Geometry Wars and Pacman CE DX. Posted: June 23, 2014
												Although LUFTRAUSERS is not a SHMUP in the traditional sense, I'm still gonna call it 'SHMUP ON DRUG' due to it's bullet hell and thre adrenaline rush.The gameplay is simple yet clever and addictive. You try to stay alive using customizable parts to suit your own play style. The 'stop-shooting-to-regenerate-health' mechanic keeps you focus on the most important part, KILL and STAY ALIVE, rather than putting you in difficult situations where you died just because you need to grab 'that healing item'The control is very responsive, although a bit confusing at first (if you're used to the six/eight axis free movement implemented in modern games), in LUFTRUASERS, you use LEFT/RIGHT to pivot/rotate your plane and UP to use the throttle/forward, but once you get used to it (and learned to master the control for the part combination you of your choice), you'll be going for the kill!AWESOME MUSICS

Posted: June 24, 2014
												Luftrausers certainly does not break new ground. But then, it doesn't have to. It is the ultimate casual (ok, hardcore casual) title when you've got 5 minutes to waste, and not a second more. It is the distilled essence of what made the classic '80s arcade games fun. There's just enough customization and variation in the game to hook you for the short timespan  that you manage to stay alive (or should I say that this is the case when you're my age and your reflexes have slowed down to a crawl). I'd recommend it to any new dad, who doesn't have all that much time to invest into gaming, and wants some mindless distraction, somewhere between work and helping the wife with the latest addition to your family.

Posted: March 30, 2014
												Certainly we've all played a bullethell shooter at some point in our lives. However, the genera does tend to get samey after a while. Enter Luftrausers, which spices up the genera with an innovative control scheme. Now, instead of managing just your position, you need to manage your momentum and direction as well, both of which can be controlled independently, giving you the ability to pull off some white-knuckle manuvers. It may take some getting used to, but once you get the hang of it, you'll be tearing up the skies with the best of 'em. Add to that a nice variety of enemies and a rocking soundtrack, and you've got one hell of a game!

												I was originally put off by this game because it looks like another "retro" indie game. Posted: September 18, 2014
												What strikes me most about this game is its sense of style -- and I don't mean something shallow here. "Style" goes not only for the graphics and music (though both are excellent), but also for the gameplay itself. Your warplane flies and tumbles in sharp but graceful arcs, allowing you to execute fun and deadly maneuvers to dodge seemingly impossible situations and bring down screen-fulls of enemies. The action is fast-paced and exciting without feeling mindless or overwhelming. While the basic idea of the game will seem very familiar -- in fact, Luftrausers would look at home in an old-fashioned arcade -- the actual gameplay experience ends up feeling quite refreshing and innovative.The graphics are simple, but very attractive, and the game definitely has its own unique look. There's a lot of detail hiding in these sepia-toned visuals. A little aircraft carrier is visible in the distance, launching those swarms of fighters you're battling. As your plane explodes, a skull-shaped mushroom cloud is visible for a split second, only to be blown away by the wind. You can tell that the art department put thought and effort into their work.The music is catchy, a kind of quasi-militaristic, but still fun, rhythm, and there's an interesting mechanic here. Your plane is composed of three different parts (weapon, body, and engine), and each has its own musical theme. The soundtrack for the game is actually the mix of these three themes put together (a mix that works quite well), and as you unlock new parts for each category, that element of the music will change, resulting in a subtly different, unique tune. It's subtle, clever, and another example of the game's attention to detail.The customizable parts also work quite well to keep the gameplay fresh. Each part you unlock will work in a completely different way, and will require a different play style. One of the body types allows you to ram enemies, but is fragile to all other damage, and will require nimbler flight and faster reflexes; one of the engines lets you plunge underwater, allowing you to evade pursuit beneath the waves, or attack battleships from below. It works to keep the game fresh. There's tons of combinations possible as you unlock new parts in each of the three categories. And each combination has its own name, highlighting the customized plane's personality! There's that attention to detail again.In short, it's a very fun, very stylish game, that seems quite simple, but has a many subtle details and fun quirks. It's perfect for quick but satisfying gaming breaks, but there's also enough here to keep you coming back, and to give you plenty of enjoyable gameplay time.

Posted: March 18, 2014
												I first tried Luftrausers at Gamescom 2013. I was waiting in line to play the highly anticipated game Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number which I was looking forward to, and while waiting someone at Devolver approached me. The man asked if I wanted to try out Luftrausers. I saw the game and thought; "♥♥♥♥, yet another arcade-shooter" I really didn't feel like playing it, but I did so I wouldn't seem like an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I'm glad that I'm not an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. The game isn't for everyone, and I thought I was one of them. I was very wrong though.There isn't much story to the game, you control a jet figher with a mission to shoot down enemy planes and boats. For every kill you aquire you get points, which also adds on to a multiplier. You then have to stack up as many points as possible. When you get more points, you level up and can aquire new plane parts and weapons.The control is really smooth. For the first 5 minutes it might prove difficult to get into, but once it sits it flows really smooth. You will get a really satisfying feeling when you manouver aroung the enemies planes and projectiles.There isn't much more to say about the game really. The premise is simple; It's fast-paced, really fun, really addicting, and VERY indie. So if you're not a fan of small and fast paced indie-gems, this might not be something for you.

Posted: May 2, 2014
												Luftrausers is a game I looked forward to greatly and was met with disappointment. The game feels short of content and costs quite a bit. Upon reaching the blimp, you may think - like I did - that the game was just beginning, but that was just false hope. The game practically ends there. Beyond beating the blimp, there lies a more difficult mode in which the blimp spawns instantly, but there's no escalation. The challenges are also quite shallow and most are far too easy to beat. The addition of extra stages, such as beating the blimp with the super engine and going to space to destroy a spaceship or beating it with the underwater engine and going deep into the sea to defeat a submarine would have been interesting, easy-to-implement additions that would have given the game some much-needed beefing out. If you like constantly striving to beat high scores, you might still consider picking the game up in a sale.

Posted: March 26, 2014
												Another outstanding indie game published by DevolverThis game is incredible.  Great action-packed gameplay, cool stylized graphics, interesting mechanics (such as repairing your ship when not firing), groovy soundtrack that is interestly impacted based on what Rauser parts you use, etc.  The combat is frantic, and reminds me of an old Konami game called Time Pilot, mostly from a control perspective.  Another great thing is that the game not only encourages, but also rewards players for trying new Rausers, rather than just sticking with the same ones, via the soundtrack and the challenges that they have for it.  This game would work great on a handheld device, due to its quick gameplay rounds, chalenges, and unlockables.  This shouldn't come as a surprise for anyone familar with Vlambeer, best known for their smash hit iOS game Ridiculous Fishing.  I totally reccomend this, but if you have a Vita (which you probably don't) you might want to get it on that, just because the game seems like it would work well on a handheld. Posted: March 18, 2014
												I first tried Luftrausers at Gamescom 2013. I was waiting in line to play the highly anticipated game Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number which I was looking forward to, and while waiting someone at Devolver approached me. The man asked if I wanted to try out Luftrausers. I saw the game and thought; "♥♥♥♥, yet another arcade-shooter" I really didn't feel like playing it, but I did so I wouldn't seem like an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I'm glad that I'm not an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. The game isn't for everyone, and I thought I was one of them. I was very wrong though.There isn't much story to the game, you control a jet figher with a mission to shoot down enemy planes and boats. For every kill you aquire you get points, which also adds on to a multiplier. You then have to stack up as many points as possible. When you get more points, you level up and can aquire new plane parts and weapons.The control is really smooth. For the first 5 minutes it might prove difficult to get into, but once it sits it flows really smooth. You will get a really satisfying feeling when you manouver aroung the enemies planes and projectiles.There isn't much more to say about the game really. The premise is simple; It's fast-paced, really fun, really addicting, and VERY indie. So if you're not a fan of small and fast paced indie-gems, this might not be something for you.

Posted: March 18, 2014
This game is a fun and easy to pick up plane game that is easy to play, but difficult to master! The controls are customizable, but some types of controlling didn't work as well as a keyboard. The d-pad on a controller doesn't work well because you have to push up to thrust and left or right to steer at the same time; all while shooting! The control sticks work fairly well but it felt like I was turning slower and I kept trying to play it like a twin-stick shooter, but it doesn't boost the way you are pointing, only up boosts you. (If any of that section made any sense, Congratulations!)The gameplay is smooth and it feels great to lead 20 planes behind you and then turn around and blast them all away! And the game provides multiple ways in which to destroy everything in sight! Each plane part changes the name of your plane and changes some small part of the soundtrack, providing a different song every time.Overall this game is a blast to play and my only complaints are that some of the control schemes take a bit of getting used to because they seem different than the keyboard and that this game could have only been better with multiplayer- local or online- would have put this game totally through the roof! 9/10 Would Luftrause again...and again...and again!

Posted: March 18, 2014
												LUFTRAUSERS is a swift, explosive ♥♥♥♥fest of badassery. Every combination of fighter is fun, and is an instant refresh for any repetition you might have forced yourself into. The music is layered with every different part you choose, so it's easy to get attached to specific combinations and tunes. Looking at the leaderboard will make you feel inadequate, and hateful. There's no nonsense in between plays, so it's easy to get back in when you've been thrashed. Just moving in LUFTRAUSERS feels amazing. Depending on which engine you choose, you could get a nice sense of weight and heft, or make graceful, broad strokes through the air. The jet engine's snappy 180s are perfect for dodging a deluge of battleship bullets. Stay low to the water with armor and a laser, then ocsillate like a metronome of DEATH. I haven't tried every combonation, but I can't imagine going wrong. Play it, and feel your stomach drop out on a dive.

Posted: March 18, 2014
												Last March I discovered Vlambeer's Ridiculous Fishing and it became my first essential smartphone game.  What makes it so compelling is that the game starts simple, yet tough and the proceeds to reward you with dozens of neat perks to slightly break the game urging you to greater depths and new areas.Luftrausers has the same formula and it's freaking brilliant.  It controls not unlike an old Lunar Lander game.  It's tough to fly and in addition your being shot at from every direction.  But it suddenly rewards you with great plane customizations ("parts") that break the game is slight, yet brilliant ways.  An engine that shoots bullets behind you, where you're not aiming.  Armor that lets you not take melee damage, at the expense of health.  An armor that explodes when you die, killing everything on screen.  The combination of the "parts" is up to you. In order to nudge you into trying new parts combinations there are a progression of missions for each part, and that's why you'll keep coming back for more.Vlambeer has once again shown that they are masters.

Posted: May 15, 2014
												Quick paced arcadey dogfighting. Gets very tense but is very exciting too. By letting go of the throttle you continue flying but can turn very rapidly by throttling in the direction you want to go, which makes larger dogfights much more about agility and compensating for your lack of it than just getting hits off. The plane can be customised by switching gun, engine and body and every customisation radically changes how you fly and even changes the goals you have to complete to better suit what you've chosen. Also, the music changes depending on what you have equipped, which is a cool feature. However, if you're pretty good you should be able to complete the game in about 2 hours if not less and in this respect it feels like you might not be getting as much bang for your buck as you would with other titles at a similar price point. You may want to consider waiting for a sale before picking this up (which I still do highly recommend).

Posted: December 2, 2015
												This will mostly echo other negative reviews but here goes.Luftrausers in itself is a great game. The controls are tight, the action is fun, and the customization is interesting. However, it's insane that what amounts to a flash game that you would find for free on the internet is sold for $10 on Steam. After a couple of hours, this game completely lost its momentum. It started out great, but it's so shallow that it made me angry that I paid $2 for it on sale.The challenges get to the point that they are too hard to have fun. I don't know how to trigger blimp appearances or make submarines show up, but when the challenge involves destroying one of those specific enemies, the frustration becomes unbearable. It ultimately just becomes a repetitious chore, and the fact that there is only one song during gameplay (which starts over every time you start a new game) doesn't help.Luftrausers is the second game I've ever bought that wound up on my "hidden" list in my games library.

Posted: March 19, 2014
												Now I know what you are thinking, is this a port of an old unknown game? Is this some unfinished mess that used to be the pinnacle of gaming tech? Luftrausers is none of those things, but it is a new take on an old working concept and by god is it entertaining.  The game is created by an indie company Vlambeer who have also created tittles like Nuclear Throne and Super Crate Box. It's in the old arcade style and features all the colour variations of the time as well as unlockable themes in the game. You miss the old pink and blue outlook of video games? Well you can unlock it and play in pink and blue.   The game itself revolves around a simple concept of shoot everything that moves and don't get killed yerself. You have the customizations options of your Rauser which is the name of the plane apparently and you can change the wings body and tail of the plane changing how it handles and behaves. For example currently my favourite set up is the Biohazard MK 2 which uses the antigrav engine, nuke body and cannon for mahussive damage.  You don't really have a set goal in the game, you have plenty of missions to do and once you defeat the blimp with any means necessary, you will be able to turn up the heat in a new difficulty mode which I haven't dared to even go to yet as there is tons of crap flying everywhere straight from the get go.  Highly recommend this little indie tittle and It is worth the pocket lint on the bottom of yer pocket easily. It is fairly short and sure it has a few bugs here and there, mainly in the menu then in the game itself,but over all it is a breath of fresh air in to the current game market and for you younger players who didn't have the good fortune to grow up in the era of arcade video games, pick this up and see the best working take on an arcade shooter that really feels a remnant from the old days. LUFTRAUSERS - Pixel Hammer

												Certainly we've all played a bullethell shooter at some point in our lives. However, the genera does tend to get samey after a while. Posted: September 18, 2014
												What strikes me most about this game is its sense of style -- and I don't mean something shallow here. "Style" goes not only for the graphics and music (though both are excellent), but also for the gameplay itself. Your warplane flies and tumbles in sharp but graceful arcs, allowing you to execute fun and deadly maneuvers to dodge seemingly impossible situations and bring down screen-fulls of enemies. The action is fast-paced and exciting without feeling mindless or overwhelming. While the basic idea of the game will seem very familiar -- in fact, Luftrausers would look at home in an old-fashioned arcade -- the actual gameplay experience ends up feeling quite refreshing and innovative.The graphics are simple, but very attractive, and the game definitely has its own unique look. There's a lot of detail hiding in these sepia-toned visuals. A little aircraft carrier is visible in the distance, launching those swarms of fighters you're battling. As your plane explodes, a skull-shaped mushroom cloud is visible for a split second, only to be blown away by the wind. You can tell that the art department put thought and effort into their work.The music is catchy, a kind of quasi-militaristic, but still fun, rhythm, and there's an interesting mechanic here. Your plane is composed of three different parts (weapon, body, and engine), and each has its own musical theme. The soundtrack for the game is actually the mix of these three themes put together (a mix that works quite well), and as you unlock new parts for each category, that element of the music will change, resulting in a subtly different, unique tune. It's subtle, clever, and another example of the game's attention to detail.The customizable parts also work quite well to keep the gameplay fresh. Each part you unlock will work in a completely different way, and will require a different play style. One of the body types allows you to ram enemies, but is fragile to all other damage, and will require nimbler flight and faster reflexes; one of the engines lets you plunge underwater, allowing you to evade pursuit beneath the waves, or attack battleships from below. It works to keep the game fresh. There's tons of combinations possible as you unlock new parts in each of the three categories. And each combination has its own name, highlighting the customized plane's personality! There's that attention to detail again.In short, it's a very fun, very stylish game, that seems quite simple, but has a many subtle details and fun quirks. It's perfect for quick but satisfying gaming breaks, but there's also enough here to keep you coming back, and to give you plenty of enjoyable gameplay time.

Posted: September 18, 2014
												This game is very arcadey; by that I mean if it cost a quarter to play you would be out hundreds of dollars very quickly. It also has the feel of many modern mobile games (the good ones) in its "mission" structure, its simple mechanics, and its combinatory building of airplanes.Basically you pilot a plane, shoot down other planes and boats, complete "missions" (i.e. destroy 10 boats total! destroy 3 aces in one combo! etc.) which unlock alternate weapons, bodies, or engines for your plane that have interesting abilities (this body makes it so you don't take damage running into other planes, this engine lets you survive in the water). These each come with their own missions to complete. The longer you survive on a level the more challenging it becomes; eventually an enormous blimp or laser-wielding super ships will appear. If you can destroy the blimp you unlock SFMT mode which is basically bullet hell. If you survive more than 30 seconds you're doing well.I thoroughly enjoyed the arcadey aspect of the game. A single play is quick, but you want to immediately jump right back in. The missions are a nice way to give you goals to work towards. I like that each combination of parts is given a unique name. It can be brutally difficult (especially SFMT mode) but it is a lot of fun.

Posted: September 19, 2014
 This has gotten my quality seal of approval. See why down below. If you like arcade style shooters, then this game is good. You have missions/objectives that you get with different weapons, armour, and engines. Once you complete some of them and level up, you might get some parts. You can mix and match and pick a mix all you like. One sad thing is that there is no stop button while playing, or, at least, it doesn't seem like it, so you'll have to use LAlt+F4. The first few achievements are easy to get, but there's an achievement you get for completing all of of the objectives, which also gives you the Urauser, which apparently is a nice and powerful ship.Things I would like to see:-ESC is for a menu that has 'Exit Game' 'Difficulty' and things like that.-An option to change the difficulty, as well as various difficulty levels.-Steam workshop for different weapons, engines, armours and enemy ships, as well as ability to make own maps with scripted events and properties, e.g. gravity, meteorites.-Options to have Arcade Style aspects on and off, an option in the main menu that you can toggle to turn off the black bars, and have less pixels/could just be split into two different options to allow for more variety.I would like to give this game an 8/10. Quite frankly, it's a really addictive game and a great way to kill time, as you will have to trouble getting the Urauser. I recommend that you get this game if you haven't already.
