Posted: March 20, 2014
												LUFTRAUSERS is a game near impossible to not admire at least a little bit during play. The combat is simlpy something to behold, as you zip across the sky in a beautiful, brown, bullet-filled sky while all hell breaks lose around you. It's a spectacle arcade SHMUP, and an extremely good one at that. It's really hard to not overplay how much fun the flying and shooting is in this game, it gives such an exhilarating and engaging feeling that's hard to find at this calibur. The game is recommendable on this aspect alone, the game is a prime example of a game that's just fun to play, you don't need any other motivation.Unfortunately, that's really all there is. The customization is limited, and a lot of the parts are kinda lack-luster in comparison to their counterparts. For example, I think the homing missiles, the cannon, the collision body, and bomb body are all utter garbage, their drawbacks all outweigh their benefits, and there are clearly better weapons. After for playing for just a few ours, the dominant strategy effect takes place and I see only three or four combinations worthy of my time. Randoming is fun as well, but a lot of the time you'll just get a back combination and die before you get anywhere really exciting. The names for each combination and mis-matched music tracks are really neat, but the novelty wears off as each match lasts just a few minutes. The missions are over in four or five hours and the SFMT, although gloriously hectic, gets a bit more frustrating than fun pretty quick. At the bottom line, the game sadly gets a little repetitive about four hours in.It's just that the game is so amazingly fun to play. Everything feels, looks, and sounds fantastic, it's a great experience. The price is a little steep for a game that gets a little old only four hours in, but if you don't mind fighting the same same seven enemy types over and over and over in rapid succession with stunted progression just for the sake of it, the game is simply and utterly fantastic.

Posted: March 24, 2014
												its a special kind of bullet hell that makes you reinvent the wheel in terms of maneuvering and return-fire.the big draws for me were the visual style, simple game design, and the modular soundtrack that changes when plane parts are swapped.in the gameplay department, the rausers are basically paper airplanes strapped to fireworks in terms of controls, rather than an actual dogfighting experience, but that's okay because it's tight as all get out.the big thing i'd have to point out  as a warning would be that the "hundreds of missions" advertised aren't actually missions, but more like side challenges implemented to your game runs, so to say? They're things like "kill 20 planes in one run" or "destroy a battleship at MAX combo" or things like that.the game design is entirely focused on a single kind of gameplay which can be altered but ultimately is the same goal every time: get kills before you get killed.I got this game for $8 with a customer loyalty coupon from Vlambeer and, if the new Metal Gear game hadn't come out on the same day, I would've seen myself playing this for a spell every few hours or so.It's addictive, but not wholly filling, so to speak. It's got that "one more time" sorta charm that's super fun, and a game you can just X out of when you're done, and boot in a second when you feel like it.I'd recommend it, ye

Posted: July 14, 2015
												This fast paced game is sure to make your heart skip a few beats. It's challenging, but rewarding when you learn a new trick or take on a new situation. The game doesn't punish you for dying, you can just get right back in the action instantly. Plus, with interchangeable ship parts, there is a lot of experimentation to be had.Apart from the gameplay, the game also has one of the most interesting and polished art styles I have seen. Eveything looks beautiful and sleek, and the looks never become obtrusive or distract the player. It also has a wonderful soundtrack that changes according to the player's ship (very impressive).Of course a review would be incomplete without some cons.Complaint 1: When you customize your controls, the game still tells you to use the default controls.Complaint 2: The game looses it's replay value very quick.Complaint 3: The short bursts of gameplay is more a trait of mobile/phone games. It's not something you will find yourself playing for more than 30 to 45 minutes at a time. (Yet, if he did port the game to mobile, the small screen and touch controls probably would not work well...)

Posted: July 18, 2015
												Disclosure: I haven't "Completed" the game per se but have played enough to understand it.Luftrausers is a game where you play as a single plane taking on a near impossible task. It's you vs everything. The entire game is essentially a massive "Objective: Survive". There are roughly 9 different enemies in the game. The consist of different things like planes, "Aces" which are super-powered planes, and (Blank, not putting the full name, since it makes it a tad obvious what they do.) aces which are super powered aces. (Scary♥♥♥♥♥♥. There is also boats, battleships, submarines and the acemarine. (Real scary♥♥♥♥♥♥. Then you have the blimp. You're on your own to find out what each of these things do how ever. The game has a form of loadout system, using 3 parts. The gun, the body and the propulsion. Part of the fun in this game is finding different insane combinations and seeing how long you'll last. The body will for instance make you slower, but with more health, or faster with little health. I personally like to play as a glass cannon, going at mach speeds, but get scratched and I die. Can lead to some fun or frustrating playthroughs.There's enough variation to keep the game fresh how ever I can say from personal experience that I feel that it's a "Go To" game. When you have moments where you just want to hop on and play a game. No story or anything like that, just pure gameplay. Each playthrough is relatively short and depends on your skill. Sometimes a minute, sometimes 10. All depends on you. The standard music is pretty great. You'll be flying down from the sky, about to take out a battle ship and the music peaks up. It really feels great, when moments like that happens. There's 2 difficulty modes from what I can see. SFMT and Normal. Essentially, hear sirens and cry. You can periodically unlock new colour schemes for the game but I didn't think any of them match up with the original, how ever if you're looking for a new experience after playing for a while. Maybe just changing the colours is all you need.Conclusion, if you're looking for a game which you can keep coming back to, that doesn't take a lot of your time, yet has enough replay value for multiple playthroughs then this is a pretty decent game. I reccomend trying it out, and if you're still skeptical then wait for a sale. It was roughly 2-3 pounds when I bought it, which is a pretty nice price.

Posted: November 3, 2015
												This is where I wish Steam had some sort of "middle ground" for reviews, as it really does pain me to give this the ol' thumbs down.  However, I can't say I'd recommend the game as an overall experience at $10, despite all that it does oh-so-right.As many others have said, the game controls great, and it really is a lot of fun zipping around and shooting stuff.  The problem is that aside from the various part-specific objectives to complete, there isn't any progression when it comes to the actual game.  You pick your parts, head into combat, fight the same random assortment of the same seven or so enemies, eventually die, then repeat.  There aren't any other levels or anything, so the game ends up feeling more like a proof of concept for a much grander concept.  I saw all the enemy types in the game within about half an hour, unlocked all the plane parts before the two hour mark, and got tired of attempting the remaining objectives soon after.Still, it was really fun and unique before I hit the "this game's really not going to throw anything else new at me, is it?" point.  While "leave them wanting more" might work to some degree, I shouldn't be wanting as much more as I am out of Luftrausers.

Posted: August 14, 2015
												Surprisingly very fun arcade-y game.I'm always skeptical when in comes to pseudo-retro games, especially ones with lo-fi graphics, but obviously this is among the good ones. Basically, you pilot a plane, avoiding bullets & missiles while shooting down your many adversaries. As you play & achieve things, you are rewarded with new plane parts interchangeable in-between runs (runs are basically infinite and can only be renewed when you die). These parts are divided into weaponry, body & thruster.However, newer parts are not necessarily superior. All parts comes with their own pluses & minuses, based on the special property it carries (like a body made of a nuclear warhead, yeah, go figure). So it depends on your combination & how you play them.Equipping certain parts also means you are only allowed to unlock certain achievements. However, this can also be used to your advantage. For example, one of the achievement missions  for the basic machine gun would be to take down a battleship. This is to say, a rather impossible task. However, if you equip your plane with the nuclear warhead body while also equpping the machine gun, you can simply run into the ship to kill it, you, and everything else on the screen and there you have it. One battleship down while 'using' the machine gun.The game doesn't have any story, but it doesn't need one anyways. The setting is enough to give you the idea that it's a war, and you are just one among the many disposable soldiers.That said, due to the nature of the game it probably has low lasting appeal. However, due to its simplicity (doesn't necessarily mean it's easy though, far from it) it's also an easy pick up and play for when you just want to play a game but isn't in the mood to think much, but still wants more or less a challenge. If you don't have a game like that in your library yet, you might want to get this.

Posted: October 26, 2015
												This game is almost as simple as a classic arcade game, yet there are some minor perks which beef the experience. Your main goal is usally to get the highest score while maximising your score multiplier, yet at the same time you are trying to complete mission objectives. finishing mission objectives unlocks parts which you can then use to customise your load out.The gameplay is fast paced difficult and satisfying. I would especially recommend it for someone who is building a modern day arcade machine or to someone who enjoys classic games like Galaga. If you are looking for a deep experience this game isn't for you, if you get frustrated quickly at games with a learning curve, don't bother. If you enjoy gaming challenge and find retro games nostalgic, this game is right up your alley. And the soundtrack is nice!

Posted: November 9, 2015
												Luftrausers is a superficially simple, but perfectly tuned dogfighting game. Before your inevitable death, you dodge, weave and stall around the enemy hordes in your custom superplane, trying to take out as many of them as you can before the end comes. Every death brings the promise of higher rankings, and more unlocked options for your craft, each with their own challenges.Something like an even more arcadey version of the old Amiga game Jetstrike!.As with all Vlambeer titles, it's also terribly hard, especially in the later stages of challenges (I'll probably never unlock everything), but the design is perfect, down to the music (which remixes for every possible custom craft!).

Posted: March 22, 2014
												This game is freakin fantastic.  Do you want a quick but addictive game that has you constantly saying "maybe just one more try" over and over again?  Then this is made for you.Luftrausers is an arcade shooter in which you pilot a fighter plane.  The controls are incredibly simple: turn left, turn right, boost, and shoot, but that's all you need to feel like the world's coolest fighter pilot.  When you let off the boost, you enter a very floaty stall that allows you to turn more quickly to get those sharp turns and finely aimed shots off.  Using your boosters in combination with stalling to dodge bullets as they fly at you from all directions is one of the coolest and most gratifying things I have experienced in a game recently.What makes this game really great is the ability to customize your plane.  As you play, you earn parts that allow you to choose your plane's weapon, body, and engine, all of which have wildly different attributes that greatly affect the way that the plane works.  This lets you mess around and customize your play style, which I find to be incredibly fun.  Each part has its own missions/challenges for you to complete (ex: Kill 10 enemies without shooting them).  These missions help you level up faster and earn more parts, so you are encouraged to keep changing things and completing different missions instead of just sticking to one plane and never changing it.Let's see, what else is great about this game?  Well, the art style is lovely and the soundtrack is incredible.  What's even cooler is that different combinations of plane parts have subtle affects on both the art and the soundtrack!So, do I recommend Luftrausers?  Absolutely and wholeheartedly!  This game is so addictive that it will have you playing for hours, and for $10, I think that's a great deal.Still not convinced?  You can play a free version of this game here: http://not.vlambeer.com/luftrauser/It doesn't have nearly as many features, but it can give you a good idea of what the gameplay is like.

Posted: March 23, 2014
												LUFTRAUSERS, further to be known as Love Trousers, is simply fantastic and I would recommend to anyone.It's clean and simple, few controls and lacking in any form of complex HUD, all of which do what they need to beautifully.  It's a chaotic bullet hell mess, fast paced and you can feel the impact of the hits.  The use of the Stall mechanic allows you to use gravity for additional control, giving a feeling and sense of movement that can make you feel like an ace.  Momentum matters.Love Trousers is an frenzied action packed game that I find very satisfying to play- and will continue playing.

Posted: January 5, 2015
												Gameplay: Luftrausers is an arcade-style shoot 'em up based around completing objectives (e.g., score 5000 points, kill a battleship at max combo). Your aircraft's weapon, body, and engine are customizable, which encourages development of different tactics. Enemy spawn inconsistency adds variety to gameplay, but leaves certain objective completions largely in the hands of chance. Given the short life of a typical game (a few minutes), this randomness is tolerable, but I wish they would have toned it down. A high level of skill is nonetheless required, but you might have to burn though several dozen attempts before enemies spawn conducive to your current objectives.Controls: Compact and elegant: left, right, accelerate, fire. Body/engine build choices yield different maneuverability, all of which feel beautifully responsive (some more than others for intentional balance reasons). Controls are the highlight of Luftrausers, and fans of arcade classics will love it for its feel.Presentation: Its simple graphics are immediately readable, and aircraft-specific musical adjustments make me feel like an angel of death. Menu navigation feels a bit clumsy. My biggest presentation gripe is during the "hardcore" SFMT mode, where you are continuously exposed to a blaring air raid siren. The only in-game way to eliminate that overwhelming sound is to disable sound effects, which are crucial to high-level gameplay. The appealing minimalist aesthetic is offset by flaws which could have been easily addressed.

Posted: January 5, 2015
												At the time they were making Luftrausers, Vlambeer was dealing with the soul crushing experience of their previous game being cloned in the iOS marketplace.  Luftrausers is their expression of a personal hell, for our entertainment!An endless cycle of death, gunfire and explosions against a enemy that will never, ever die.  Only respawn in greater numbers.  The most effective weapon is a nuclear explosion that will take your enemies with you.  A dank soundtrack that sounds like a march to war, evolving as you play, but keeping the same plodding theme.After playing this game with headphones on a few nights ago, I achieved that wonderful state of videogameness where I could not leave the screen, putting all 3 settings on random and falling into such a groove with the constanly changing soundtrack that I found myself humming it all day afterward.

Posted: August 9, 2015
												Alright, so here's how this works. Its a bullet hell game. No story mode, nothing like that. You go out in your plane,  you shoot boats, planes, missles, etc, you die. a lot. however, you have objectives, like "Kill 5 boats". When you do these, you can unlock new parts that change the way it works. Your plane might have a laser and go really fast, or it could shoot 5 shots at once but be really tanky. there's even a body which is a nuke that kills everything when you die. Its the same idea, but with different ways to play and my god is it addictive. oh and ♥♥♥♥ battleships. but for the price, its alright. maybe wait for a sale, but yeah. :)

Posted: June 16, 2015
												Luftrausers is an intense bullet-hell that should be an essential arcade-style game for every Steam library. The game uses achievable, relatively simple goals to give purpose to your gameplay, offers simple, straightforward customization that allows for a diverse array of gameplay styles, and allows high accessibility to almost anyone as a result. The art style and sountrack both feel consistent and fitting for the game.Pros: Highly Accessible Simple, diverse customization Variety and excitement that lasts Consistent design and fitting soundtrack A simple, motivating sense of accomplishment as pieces are unlocked and objectives are completedCons: Controls take a while to get used to, but feel great once you've adjusted Options menu to change your controls is an input button pressing sequenceI'd recommend this game to just about anyone looking for an arcade bullet hell. The game is just slightly under becoming too chaotic for me, and I prefer it that way.

Posted: June 23, 2015
												I played this game for 20 minutes or so, since I'm gonna force myself to play games that aren't CSGO.The game is very simple, almost no menu. All you have to do to restart when you die is press up on the joystick, and a new plane will launch.The controlls are a little awkward at first. Press up to go in the direction you are pointing, left and right to spin. You get the hang of it after a few rounds. Just as I thought I had enough after 3-4 rounds, I unlocked new plane parts. Now I can shoot a laser beam. And that made a huge difference. Then I unlocked engine parts that gave me more armor, move slower, and spin a little faster.From what I can tell, the game is simple, but enjoyable. Easy to pick up and put down. Would definitely recommend this game for $2-3 bucks, which I believe it goes on sale for. If you already own it, install it and play it for 30 minutes or so.

Posted: January 5, 2015
												Maybe I'm not on the same page as everyone with this game, but I feel like it's a borderline frustration game.The customization makes the gameplay very different each time you equip different items. This gives the game a lot more play time, and diversity, since the combinations of items makes you basically start from scratch to learn how to control your plane.You need to work very hard to feel satisfaction in this game. It takes a bit to get used maneuvering your plane, and even when you do the feeling of being shot down after a mere 2 minutes can be enough to make someone take a sledgehammer to their controller.For those who love an Asteroid-style Shmup and an intense challenge, get this game. For me though, the frustration of trying to progress gives me a similar feeling that I got while playing Flappy Birds.

Posted: January 25, 2015
												Alright, before we get going, I'll say right off the bat this game is not worth $10.  I might even go so far as to say it's not worth $5.  It's definitely a game you should only buy on special.Now, with that out of the way, let me start with the highlights of the game.The graphics and music are excellent, I love the artstyle in general, it's very quirky and has a lot of personality.  The game is quite difficult but simple to play.  Easy to pick up but hard to master certainly applies here, especially if you're going for points.Now, for the bad bits. Just a forewarning, this negative impression might be coloured by my own level of skill as opposed to the game itself, but either way, here's my two cents.Though the slightly random generation of the levels does help, it doesn't feel like there's quite enough enemy variety, at least not as far as I've seen. Perhaps there's much more if you survive for a lot longer than I have but I'm a bit skeptical.The game also focuses on combo chaining to get points but after you clear the initial wave of little planes that chase you, and if you're good enough to clear out the boats, all you're left with to kill are huge battleships, large aircraft that move much faster than you do and have a large chunk of HP, and massive airships (if you're lucky enough to have them spawn at all).  All of these enemies have too much HP for your weapons (which don't increase in power throughout your run) to take down with any efficiency, and the 5 second timer for your combo meter is not nearly generous enough for you to get more than a couple multipliers before it resets at this point.  There are still the cruise missiles and the fighter jets that streak around but the cruise missiles don't seem to appear in enough quantity and the fighter jets are too fast to reliably shoot down to keep up your combo meter.Also, speaking of the points, due to the flaws that I perceive in the score system, it is difficult to get much more than 10,000 points in a successful run, which makes unlocking new parts a bit of a grind since it can take tens of thousands of points to unlock a single new part for your plane later on.The final nail in the coffin for me is also the fact that, despite the interesting range of part combinations that you can put together in this game to create your own unique vehicle, I ended up feeling that the only combination that really worked to survive and score with any efficiency was pretty much laser + high HP body + fast engine.  The HP difference between the high HP body and everything else rendered almost all the other bodies moot, especially when you pair the high HP body with the high speed engine.  It doesn't help that all of these parts are quite literally the first set of parts you unlock.Clearly some of this is subjective in how you approach the game, how good of a player you are, and which body combination works for you (though it's hard to imagine how any of the other bodies could surpass the massive HP difference of the high HP body), but I feel the scoring system, weapon unlock system, and the unviability of the various part combinations makes this a frustrating experience that quickly becomes repetitive.

												Great arcade shoot-em-up. If you can't afford the ten dollar entrance fee, try out the free version of this game, it's awesome! Just search for Luftrauser and you'll find the prototype. Posted: January 7, 2015
												From when I first turned it on, I was unable to stop playing this great game for nearly 5 hours. The feedback loop of just one more round along with no waiting time between attempts just kept me hooked. It has a great soundtrack, one which works amazingly when your ship is in critical condition while the heroic refrain of the track blazes high as you thread the needle through a sea of bullets and coming out the other side! The core gameplay mechanic is a joy to play with.There are some issues, notably it does not make it obvious how to quit (you can quit on the screen with the carrier). Along the same lines is that its menus could had done better. Some of the mission design (for unlocking new parts and giving you goals to work for) could had been better. Some of the parts could be better balanced. The game does seem perhaps a little too hard. Mostly in that I shake my fists at those pesky battleships, especially when more than one start stacking together to make a cloud of death. Yet as hard as the game is, you can eventually lock a mode which turns the game into a literal bullet hell.But on the whole, it was very enjoyable and a great surprise. Highly recommended.

Posted: May 1, 2014
												An awful trip to a level of graphics that really should be left in an era, circa 1988. I understand the 'retro' need for nostalgia - with the 16 (and sometimes) 8-bit looking games being popular these last couple of years. But this really does dip to a whole new level.Essentially, you've got a weird hybrid game of Altitude meeting a set piece from Access's classic Beach-Head from 1984. Except both of these games are more fun. Anyone old enough to remember another classic - Domark's 'Wings of Fury' will also find this familiar - but again, the shooting planes and attacking ships was much better done in that game too.I really am puzzled as to what they were trying to achieve with this game. It feels clumsy, truly horrific to look at in 2014 and just ultimately a very boring, bland game to play. I really wish I'd bothered with a demo before forking out even my measely £6.99 for it. It's not even worth that.1/10

Posted: February 1, 2015
												Luftrausers, no idea what it means. But who the ♥♥♥♥ cares!? It's ♥♥♥♥ing Luftrausers!! It's a welcome addition to the arcade bullet-hell genre, and it's a jackpot of interesting mechanics. In a way it's not even a traditional arcady bullet-hell game. It's a very modern take on the classics, with it's beautiful art style and smooth pixel-by-pixel animations. It is truly a work of art, and I recommend it to anyone looking for a quick achievment hunt, or a simple game to play on a laptop. Luftrausers is also available on Playstation Vita and Playstation 3 systems.

Posted: February 3, 2015
												Graphics: 2/3Story: 1/3Game Play: 3/3Re-playable: 1/1Sale Rate: 20%Total: 7/10Graphics: 2/3The game has a clean Indy style focusing on brown scale tones with large bullets so you can easily see and sometimes dodge them. Your own plane looks different enough that it doesn’t get lost in the fighting without it looking foolish and too cartoony. Everything sticks nicely to the games aesthetic and it looks like an old arcade machine. The music has a marching drive to it, spurring you on. There is a weird choice to make the music track restart on launch so if you die in the first few seconds you hear a sharp stop and start of the soundtrack. Story: 1/3As far as I can tell, you are a German flying the most advance plane in the war. The evil Churchill has declared total war against the Glorious Third Reich and only you can stop his relentless assault over the British Channel. You fight not for glory or for riches, you fight for the survival of your glorious empire. I don’t know if this was made by Germans or someone simply said, “you know what we have too much of? The Allies' side of the war. Let’s change that”. It wasn’t until I killed Churchill in his war zeppelin that I realized I was playing as a German. Since this is a score attack rogue-like game, it doesn’t need a story or dialog to keep you playing. It does create a uniform world with some discovery, but no great mystery. Doesn’t add or subtract anything.Game Play: 3/3This game gives some great visuals to assist your gameplay. There is no health bar or ammo, thereis only the dog fight. There is no power ups or health drops, there is only the dog fight. There are no allies, there is only the dog fight.When you take damage, the screen starts to get narrower. To regen health, you just stop shooting. Enemies play by the same rules as you, when you crash you lose health, but you might kill the enemy. To accomplish this your plane can maintain speed after you stop thrusting. So you can fly across the screen while shooting backwards. The controls are tight and the feedback is instant. There is a large number of supported play styles with different planes geared directly for. At a certain point you get a randomizer to add a new element to the game. Re-Playability: 1/1You unlock new parts after you die, and there is one plane body that turns you into a nuke on death. Should you buy it?I had more fun playing this with friends than alone. Has some good value, but nothing world changing, buy on a lite sale. Note: single player only, you need friends in room.

												Luftrauser is in all likelihood the crunchiest and most enlightened retro shooter anyone in any dimension will ever play.  They give you the tools but you are your own worst enemy.   A perfect combination of simplicity, retro-style and skill.  Most importantly, the game feels fair.  When I lose I know I facked up.Possible con:  They changed the game mechanic from the original flash game.  It was really cool too.  Your plane went into a default counter-clockwise loop spin stall when not engaging engine which allowed for quick directional extractions.  They changed the mechanic to where there is no auto-loop when disengaging thrust..  now you control direction completely.  It's different but not better or worse.  So on that note I would seriously like to see an option to play in the original gamestyle which was quite compelling in its own right.P.S.  Hours played irrelevant.  Luftrauser is not shy in revealing its genius.

Posted: August 8, 2014
												Luftrausers is a game with amazing mechanics that is sadly marred by some borderline unreasonable objectives later into the game.The main draw of Luftrausers is the beautifully responsive flight mechanics that you get to play with. By cutting your engine, you are able to 'stall' in the air, allowing you to shoot in any direction as your craft is carried on by momentum and gravity. I cannot dexcribe how awesome it feels to arc over a battleship as you sweep your lasers across its hull, or blow a tailing enemy squadron out of the sky with a well timed cannon shot as you fall backwards towards the ocean.And yes, you do have multiple weapons options for your 'rauser' (plane). There are a number of customisation options for the guns, hull and engine, which are unlocked by some algorithm tied into mission completion (see next paragraph). Though these seemingly offer different playstyles, and add something to the progession model of the game, I found that a significant number of 'upgrades' were rendered (sometimes immediately) obsolete by clearly better alternatives. For example, the nuke body will perform a screen-wipe upon your death, but these kills aren't added to your score. So apart from helping with a small number of 'kill [X]' missions, this body is outright inferior to the body that just buffs your health.Though the game is designed to be like an old-school arcade game where the main objective is maximising score, for each customisation option, there is a short string of sub-objectives. This allows you to attempt up to three missions per round, with one tied to each part of your ship. These start out simple enough, but by the end of the game, they start to veer into RNG-fests that require you to kill high-profile enemies at maximum combo. (Kill an enemy to increase combo by 1, maxes at 20; standard combo fare.) But this requires you to get a max combo, sustain a max combo, and do the three-plus attack runs required to kill the target, all in one round. If that target never spawns (submarines, you scumbags!), then tough luck. I found myself quitting out of frustration after a while, because of the increasingly unreasonable missions.Having made those complains, I am still reccomending this game. Why? Because 'I cannot dexcribe how awesome it feels to arc over a battleship as you sweep your lasers across its hull'. I don't know how much life you'll get out of this game (it depends on your levels of perseverance), but it's cheap and the core mechanics are just that good.

Posted: August 22, 2014
												In Luftrausers there's only one "level". You can play this level with a great number of different planes, and each plane has its own missions, for example: "Destroy 2 Battleships"; "Kill x enemies without taking damage". It's incredibly addictive, as you unlock new ship parts and tick off the missions assigned to each one. The controls are tight, yet fluid, and when you pull off deft maneuvers to weave through a hail of bullets, while at the same time taking down the swarm of fighters giving chase, you know you're a dogfighting ace.The game is brimming over with that Vlambeer 'juice': screenshakes, masses of particles, crunchy explosions and tactile mini-pauses and slowdown. This is a game that feels great to play, and that's why a single level has kept me playing for hours. Granted, when the missions became very difficult, I started to feel like I was putting more into the game than I was getting out of it. At that point it was time to hang up my aviator's hat and goggles. But to have kept me playing so long with so little is testament to the mechanics and polish of the game.

Posted: May 19, 2014
												I remember the first time I ever played this when it was still just a flash game. It was an OK game at best... just another typical arcade shooter adapted for use with web browsers. It certainly wasn't my favorite. The design seemed minimalist and the gameplay was not very satisfying, and the controls had quite a learning curve.Then, I saw this on Steam... and I thought, "Why the hell not?"Honestly, that was a solid decision.Upon playing Luftrausers again, I felt an odd satisfaction in the way that the game had changed. The visuals were improved, albeit with the same graphical style, which really did feel pretty nice. I noticed also the in-game menus that the previous version lacked as well. When I launched my rauser for the first time, I struggled a bit with the controls but after a few tries I felt very maneuverable. The increased enemies and enemy variety made the game interesting enough to play.Upon returning to the hangar after a few unsuccessful missions, I found customizing my rauser and testing it out to be quite entertaining. I put together something that I thought would compliment my play style and I was not disappointed. After unlocking more parts, I prioritized experimenting to find a good combination. Needless to say, having the customization option that the prequel lacked is enthralling.Between the updated graphics, the customization, and the unique enemies, I would say that this is one of the best arcade games I have ever played. The amount of satisfaction is overwhelming. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys arcade-style shooters. I will be having lots of fun with this game in the near future.

Posted: April 6, 2015
												Luftrausers is a nice little arcade shooter. It's good at what it does, and doesn't pretend to be anything more than that. There's no multiplayer, no additional maps or levels, no extended story or plot. Just fly around and shoot as much stuff as you can until you inevitably die.The various upgrades to your weapon, body, and engine types have meaningful differences on gameplay and strategy. There are enough combinations - and incentives to try them - that the upgrade system extended my playtime longer than I expected. I found it to be a pretty difficult game, and it took a while for me to get acclimated to the control scheme, but I had fun with it. Easily worth the price of admission.

Posted: July 17, 2014
												Luftrausers is a fantastic shooter with simple controls.  As you play the game you can customize your rauser in 3 parts.  The gun, the body and the engine.  Each different part that you select unlocks different goals to achieve.  Ultimately there is one level with different challenges.  The more you play the more you level up (Max out at lvl 10).  You will also unlock different color schemes.  After you unlock everything you are essentially playing for points.  So design your favorite rauser and see how you compare to the rest of the world.  The gameplay is fast and fun.  The music is actually pretty good.  It is half German national music with hints of techno.  The original color scheme gives you that old timey WWII feel.  You can definitely put a good number of hours in on this game trying to unlock all the achievements and get a kick♥♥♥♥♥score.  I highly recommend it.

Posted: July 17, 2014
												Fast paced, brutally difficult, and beautiful 2D arcade shooter. You play as a customizeable superweapon and lay waste to clouds of fighter planes, massive battleships and submarines, and more. Pros- Tight control scheme with very enjoyable ship physics. You can easily pick up the game and play with little experience, and you will also learn fancy maneuvers over time and get better at dodging the clouds of bullets and missles that await you.- Great ship customization, switching ship weapon, chassis, and engines. 125 possible ships (and one secret ship). - Nice 2-D art, with fantastic animations. In addition to the sepia classic color scheme are a range of unlockable color palettes which cause varying amounts of eye-bleed.- Cool chiptune soundtrack. Your choice of ship parts will change elements of the soundtrack.- Nice missions system for every ship part. Completing missions unlock other ship parts, ship backgrounds, and the punishing difficulty mode SFMT.- I have personally never experienced any glitches or performance issues. HOWEVER: When you collide with another ship, gametime runs a little more slowly, and you might think the game is running choppily when this happens.Neutral- Extremely difficult gameplay, especially in the SFMT mode. Game quickly becomes a bullet hell, with quite low ship health and only one life per run. You will die a lot. You might like that.- Two difficulty modes, normal (quite difficult) and SFMT (virtually impossible). SFMT is difficult enough that you get an achievement for surviving 13 seconds.- Purely arcade game modes, no story or multiplayer to speak of. It's all focused on the gameplay, so if you don't dig the 2D dogfighting there's nothing here for you.- Some aspects of the game are very RNG based. You can get missions to kill specific enemy types that appear some small percentage of the time.Cons- Two of the achievements are obnoxiously difficult to complete, compared to the others. You will complete every achievement except the last two by 15 hours of gameplay. You might want to contact a mental health representative before attempting to complete all achievements in this game.- Visual style can make it difficult to understand exactly how damaged you are. You will often think you can eat a bullet that ends up killing you.- While the chiptune soundtrack can be customized a bit by your decision of ship parts, it has the exact same structure and mostly sounds the same between different combinations. It can be tedious, but you can always mute it and play your own music when you get tired of it.OVERALL: For me, this is an excellent arcade game. Great controls, exciting difficult gameplay, and a really fun aesthetic. All of my cons, besides the first one, are pretty small gripes, and for me the neutral points are mostly positive. I highly recommend the game.

Posted: July 2, 2014
												First off, let me just state two facts:1) Luftrausers is a fast-paced arcade-style flight game in which you pilot a modular fighter plane in the service of a military organization whose design is unsettlingly reminiscent of a certain loathed German political and ideological regime dating back to the late-1930's to mid-1940's.2) Luftrausers has been widely praised as stupidly fun and brilliantly well-designed and no one seems to give a rat's patoot about the disturbing portion of fact #1.The game's premise is simple enough: you're a fighter pilot whose plane is launched from a battleship in enemy territory, and you must shoot down every plane, ship, and other you encounter. Downing foes in rapid succession nets you combos to your score, making it much easier to get high scores through efficient and deadly play. Although you can repair your plane by simply getting out of combat and not shooting for a little while, you can only take a few hits before you explode; flying through enemy fire may be the right move on occasion, but try to avoid taking more than you can handle. Regardless, play is swift and death is rarely very painful - after each game, you get a quick recap of your stats, see what you've unlocked, adjust your equipment loadout, and get back in the skies almost immediately.Apart from the constant compulsion to get higher and higher scores, the game throws other goals at you as you progress, such as downing X of a certain unit in a single game, or as part of a single combo, or while entirely uninjured. Completing these unlocks new modular components for your plane (guns, engines, or body types), each of which significantly changes gameplay and comes with its own brand new set of goals.The actual gameplay is simple, but demands heavy skill. Pushing Up activates your thrust, causing you to move in whichever direction you're currently facing. Left and Right turn your ship, and X rains blazing death upon your foes. You only recover while not shooting, and you can turn much more quickly without the thrust on, so combat winds up involving a lot of careful boosts, drifting past the enemy, lighting them up with gunfire, and then boosting away to safety. Or it might involve vicious divebombing and kamikaze tactics. Or strafing from a safe distance. Or letting your rear-mounted guns take out pursuing units. As I said, your build drastically changes the gameplay, and you'll often find impossible goals become possible when you trade one component out for another. Chasing goals is surprisingly satisfying, and it's easy to lose several hours to the game when you only intended to play a couple quick rounds.Whether the game's disturbing aesthetic pushes or breaks the boundaries of good taste is up to you. There's no actual Nazi symbolism or behavior present in the game, but the motif and vibe is certainly there, and if that's a deal-breaker, that's perfectly understandable. However, the game itself is polished and perfect enough that I really do have to endorse it to anyone who enjoys unorthodox bullet hell gameplay and one of the finest customization systems in gaming history.

												An arcade-style game where you fly your highly-customisable plane around, destroying all of the other planes and avoiding being destroyed. Posted: October 8, 2014
												Luftrausers is the fairly new arcade shmup from Vlambeer, who is best known for their indie hit Super Crate Box. Super Crate Box, while a freeware and simplistic shoot-em-up game that probably isn't meant to have hours dumped into, was incredibly addicting and I ended up spending around 17 to 18 hours playing it total (not counting the occasional rainy afternoon I pick it up for a half hour before not touching it for weeks). Even though I haven't put that much time yet into Luftrausers, I'm already hooked. The gameplay starts off simple: you're a plane. You shoot other planes and boats. That's it. However, once you start really playing it and improving your game, you start unlocking new parts and start finding some more enemies, such as the blimp. And that's where Luftrausers shines: it's so simple, yet gets more "complex" as you get better. The gameplay, while pretty much the same thing over and over and over again, is enthralling and addictive--it's suffice to say that Luftrausers is one of those "just one more turn" ordeals. Enemy AI is well-done, often moving around and dodging your bullets, causing you to really make split-second strategical decisions so that you don't crash and burn. The customization is rich and adds a whole different aspect not seen in other Vlambeer titles, with dozens of engines, weapons, and bodies to scroll through and unlock. And the soundtrack is amazingly done, a truly beautiful symphony that adds to the "gotta move fast!" aspect of the game. My only gripe is the lack of VARIATION in the gameplay, but it's one that I'm not losing sleep over.OVERALL, Luftrausers is a gem of a game, combining sleek and stylish bullet-hell gameplay with well-done customization and a brilliant soundtrack. If you love Vlambeer or shmups, this is not to be missed. 9.5/10

Posted: January 7, 2015
												From when I first turned it on, I was unable to stop playing this great game for nearly 5 hours. The feedback loop of just one more round along with no waiting time between attempts just kept me hooked. It has a great soundtrack, one which works amazingly when your ship is in critical condition while the heroic refrain of the track blazes high as you thread the needle through a sea of bullets and coming out the other side! The core gameplay mechanic is a joy to play with.There are some issues, notably it does not make it obvious how to quit (you can quit on the screen with the carrier). Along the same lines is that its menus could had done better. Some of the mission design (for unlocking new parts and giving you goals to work for) could had been better. Some of the parts could be better balanced. The game does seem perhaps a little too hard. Mostly in that I shake my fists at those pesky battleships, especially when more than one start stacking together to make a cloud of death. Yet as hard as the game is, you can eventually lock a mode which turns the game into a literal bullet hell.But on the whole, it was very enjoyable and a great surprise. Highly recommended.

Posted: February 19, 2015
												I would absolutely recommend this game if it was working properly. When it was functioning it was a great, fast paced, shootemup with an interesting graphical style that was very pleasing to the eye while being very simple. The challenges presented for each module of your aircraft produce a feeling that makes you want to keep playing. Unlocking new parts and guns for the planes reaches its peak rather quickly, if you play well, so having teh challenges present for each module is a nice touch.Thats all the good i will say...The game worked great on my work pc, which was the first pc i installed it on. However when i tried to install the game on my gaming rig later that day, the game would not even get past the opening screen without one of about a million different variations of glitches would take over, making it impossible for me to even start flying a plane.I tried every fix i could find online and contacted the developers through the message boards. I got one reply initially that led me nowhere and then the devs seemed to just give up and abandon the message boards entirely. After not getting any replies to my numerous posts and questions for over 4 months i gave up on that idea. Tried to contact them by email. No luck. Back to fixes. you guessed it, no luck whatsoever.Now i am stuck with a game that will only run on my work computer, that i can scarcely play only when i am on break or waiting around after work for a colleague. The worst part is I ACTUALLY ENJOY THE GAME!I just wish the devs would have helped me and plenty others in fixing the major issues with the game. It really bothers me that i hear thorugh the boards they are already working on their next game (so now my hopes for fixing 'Luftrausers' is really crushed) and "have been through some tough times" so try to understand. I paid $10 for an indie title, so quite frankly, I ain't understandin' sh*t!

												Luftrausers is a nice little arcade shooter. It's good at what it does, and doesn't pretend to be anything more than that. There's no multiplayer, no additional maps or levels, no extended story or plot. Just fly around and shoot as much stuff as you can until you inevitably die.The various upgrades to your weapon, body, and engine types have meaningful differences on gameplay and strategy. There are enough combinations - and incentives to try them - that the upgrade system extended my playtime longer than I expected. I found it to be a pretty difficult game, and it took a while for me to get acclimated to the control scheme, but I had fun with it. Easily worth the price of admission.

Posted: December 27, 2014
												A lot of people say that this game is a pile of crap and that it's too hard or too short or too repeatative. Most of them would be right; It's too hard, too short and too repeatative, but it's definitely not crap in my opinion. What evolved from a flash game had come a long way into being what it is today. I've played many bullet hells in my youth, from Striker 1942 to Project Raiden to Sylpheed and even the unknown gem that is Einhander. Most of these games however are just lightweights to the REAL bullet hells that are out there hoever; you know, the kind that have and entire screen lit up with bullets that can only be dodged by a simple tap of the joy-stick as you just BARELY make it through alive? Yeah those make this game look like a chump, but never the less, this is in fact a bullethell game.It's a hard game to play, but the controls are simple to master. Once you understand the controls and have a better understanding of the momentum/physics mechanic of this game, the rest is left up to ou and your own skill. This game starts off simple enough, but eventually gets harder and hard with each enemy you destroy. You'll pit off against standard planes, PT boats, Jets, Battleships, Aces, missle launching submarines and even enormous blimps that act as floating combat stations. I found the game quite enjoyable, well when I wasn't trying to unlock new weapons by completeing acheivements for each peice of equipment I had on my plane. However even though I found the game quite fun, it has it's small flaws.The game only has on song, but the song changes depending on what chasis, weapon and engine you equip. After a while of progress eventually the enemies will start to swarm you, making it almost impossible to maneuvar as enemies seem to focus more on ramming into you with no self preservation and filling up the air with a seemingly endless barrage of bullets. Some acheivements are almost impossible to complete unless the stars are aligned just right and the gods of chaos decide that it is time for you to complete your calling. Finally, once you destroy a blimp, the supposed "boss" of this game, the enemy will begin to throw everything at you INCLUDING the kitchen sink and then some, which is where you'll realize that this is pretty much when the game's decided "ok it's over, you can die now."Even with these flaws though, the gameplay feels so good and satisfying, and the music is pretty catchy, even though it's starting to lose its touch. It's a guilty pleasure that I love to play and I would recommend that people play it at least once.

Posted: June 23, 2014
												Although LUFTRAUSERS is not a SHMUP in the traditional sense, I'm still gonna call it 'SHMUP ON DRUG' due to it's bullet hell and thre adrenaline rush.The gameplay is simple yet clever and addictive. You try to stay alive using customizable parts to suit your own play style. The 'stop-shooting-to-regenerate-health' mechanic keeps you focus on the most important part, KILL and STAY ALIVE, rather than putting you in difficult situations where you died just because you need to grab 'that healing item'The control is very responsive, although a bit confusing at first (if you're used to the six/eight axis free movement implemented in modern games), in LUFTRUASERS, you use LEFT/RIGHT to pivot/rotate your plane and UP to use the throttle/forward, but once you get used to it (and learned to master the control for the part combination you of your choice), you'll be going for the kill!AWESOME MUSICS

Posted: June 24, 2014
												Luftrausers certainly does not break new ground. But then, it doesn't have to. It is the ultimate casual (ok, hardcore casual) title when you've got 5 minutes to waste, and not a second more. It is the distilled essence of what made the classic '80s arcade games fun. There's just enough customization and variation in the game to hook you for the short timespan  that you manage to stay alive (or should I say that this is the case when you're my age and your reflexes have slowed down to a crawl). I'd recommend it to any new dad, who doesn't have all that much time to invest into gaming, and wants some mindless distraction, somewhere between work and helping the wife with the latest addition to your family.

Posted: May 6, 2014
												"If you like that or any kind of arcade bullet hell games, or, Hell, if you even like planes, Pick this up"This was a free to play flash game. A very good one infact, a game based around the ability of stalling. They made it just right, so that you can dodge bullets by stalling and really get that feel of being an ace pilot. Now this game is a proper title, with the same graphics, but there is so much more replayability than before and the last game had a good amount.The first improvement is the options now is a thing. Allowing you to change several things, but also adding filters, which you dont see in many games. Secondly their are new units, that make the game so much more harder, even though it seems that the units from the last game seem to be stronger aswell. Lastly and so far my favorite, CUSTOMIZATION! You have several parts to put together a plane, that each has a diffrent playstyle and an interesting name to boot. This allows you to build a plane of your liking, Want a tankier plane, put a bigger hull, Want a lazer instead of a machinegun, You got it! This really adds alot to a game that was free.The game is also hard as nails. It is difficult to get anywhere, and several runs will be more than certain. Not only that, after you defeat a boss that will not be named, You get SFMT mode, which i cannot begin to touch due to the bullet hell that it creates. Aside, I have not seen a single bug, no crashes, no misplaced textures, This is probably due to the simplicity, Graphics are very basic, This means it pretty much run on anything, probably even a calculator, but its slightly hideous.If you are questioning if its worth it, type up luftrauser in a search engine, find the flash version. If you like that or any kind of arcade bullet hell games, or, Hell, if you even like planes, Pick this up, its cheap and is extremely replayable.8/10

Posted: November 3, 2015
												This is where I wish Steam had some sort of "middle ground" for reviews, as it really does pain me to give this the ol' thumbs down.  However, I can't say I'd recommend the game as an overall experience at $10, despite all that it does oh-so-right.As many others have said, the game controls great, and it really is a lot of fun zipping around and shooting stuff.  The problem is that aside from the various part-specific objectives to complete, there isn't any progression when it comes to the actual game.  You pick your parts, head into combat, fight the same random assortment of the same seven or so enemies, eventually die, then repeat.  There aren't any other levels or anything, so the game ends up feeling more like a proof of concept for a much grander concept.  I saw all the enemy types in the game within about half an hour, unlocked all the plane parts before the two hour mark, and got tired of attempting the remaining objectives soon after.Still, it was really fun and unique before I hit the "this game's really not going to throw anything else new at me, is it?" point.  While "leave them wanting more" might work to some degree, I shouldn't be wanting as much more as I am out of Luftrausers.

Posted: June 13, 2014
												One word review: a-RAUS-ingWhat can I say about this game that will do it justice? Short answer. Buy. This. Game.Luftrausers is a 2D, bullet hell, combo based dogfighting game which sees you playing as what is essentially a Nazi fighter pilot in not-so-WW2. You customise your "Rauser" with tonns of different parts that have their powers and weaknesses, like an engine that lets you fly underwater, but will receive more damage if you fly too high, or a body that explodes like a nuclear bomb when you die, allowing you to do a last ditch Kamikaze into one of the many enemies wanting to ruin your day. You can customise your weapon system, your body, and your engine. Depending on which parts you pick will affect the soundtrack in drastic ways. Overall, this game is an absolute gem. Any PC can run it, it has a load of replayability, an amazing soundtrack, slick retro visuals and at a fiver, its a bargain. Pick it up and get Rausing.

Posted: March 22, 2014
												This game is freakin fantastic.  Do you want a quick but addictive game that has you constantly saying "maybe just one more try" over and over again?  Then this is made for you.Luftrausers is an arcade shooter in which you pilot a fighter plane.  The controls are incredibly simple: turn left, turn right, boost, and shoot, but that's all you need to feel like the world's coolest fighter pilot.  When you let off the boost, you enter a very floaty stall that allows you to turn more quickly to get those sharp turns and finely aimed shots off.  Using your boosters in combination with stalling to dodge bullets as they fly at you from all directions is one of the coolest and most gratifying things I have experienced in a game recently.What makes this game really great is the ability to customize your plane.  As you play, you earn parts that allow you to choose your plane's weapon, body, and engine, all of which have wildly different attributes that greatly affect the way that the plane works.  This lets you mess around and customize your play style, which I find to be incredibly fun.  Each part has its own missions/challenges for you to complete (ex: Kill 10 enemies without shooting them).  These missions help you level up faster and earn more parts, so you are encouraged to keep changing things and completing different missions instead of just sticking to one plane and never changing it.Let's see, what else is great about this game?  Well, the art style is lovely and the soundtrack is incredible.  What's even cooler is that different combinations of plane parts have subtle affects on both the art and the soundtrack!So, do I recommend Luftrausers?  Absolutely and wholeheartedly!  This game is so addictive that it will have you playing for hours, and for $10, I think that's a great deal.Still not convinced?  You can play a free version of this game here: http://not.vlambeer.com/luftrauser/It doesn't have nearly as many features, but it can give you a good idea of what the gameplay is like.

Posted: March 23, 2014
												LUFTRAUSERS, further to be known as Love Trousers, is simply fantastic and I would recommend to anyone.It's clean and simple, few controls and lacking in any form of complex HUD, all of which do what they need to beautifully.  It's a chaotic bullet hell mess, fast paced and you can feel the impact of the hits.  The use of the Stall mechanic allows you to use gravity for additional control, giving a feeling and sense of movement that can make you feel like an ace.  Momentum matters.Love Trousers is an frenzied action packed game that I find very satisfying to play- and will continue playing.

Posted: March 18, 2014
This game is a fun and easy to pick up plane game that is easy to play, but difficult to master! The controls are customizable, but some types of controlling didn't work as well as a keyboard. The d-pad on a controller doesn't work well because you have to push up to thrust and left or right to steer at the same time; all while shooting! The control sticks work fairly well but it felt like I was turning slower and I kept trying to play it like a twin-stick shooter, but it doesn't boost the way you are pointing, only up boosts you. (If any of that section made any sense, Congratulations!)The gameplay is smooth and it feels great to lead 20 planes behind you and then turn around and blast them all away! And the game provides multiple ways in which to destroy everything in sight! Each plane part changes the name of your plane and changes some small part of the soundtrack, providing a different song every time.Overall this game is a blast to play and my only complaints are that some of the control schemes take a bit of getting used to because they seem different than the keyboard and that this game could have only been better with multiplayer- local or online- would have put this game totally through the roof! 9/10 Would Luftrause again...and again...and again!

Posted: March 18, 2014
												LUFTRAUSERS is a swift, explosive ♥♥♥♥fest of badassery. Every combination of fighter is fun, and is an instant refresh for any repetition you might have forced yourself into. The music is layered with every different part you choose, so it's easy to get attached to specific combinations and tunes. Looking at the leaderboard will make you feel inadequate, and hateful. There's no nonsense in between plays, so it's easy to get back in when you've been thrashed. Just moving in LUFTRAUSERS feels amazing. Depending on which engine you choose, you could get a nice sense of weight and heft, or make graceful, broad strokes through the air. The jet engine's snappy 180s are perfect for dodging a deluge of battleship bullets. Stay low to the water with armor and a laser, then ocsillate like a metronome of DEATH. I haven't tried every combonation, but I can't imagine going wrong. Play it, and feel your stomach drop out on a dive.

Posted: March 20, 2014
												LUFTRAUSERS is a game near impossible to not admire at least a little bit during play. The combat is simlpy something to behold, as you zip across the sky in a beautiful, brown, bullet-filled sky while all hell breaks lose around you. It's a spectacle arcade SHMUP, and an extremely good one at that. It's really hard to not overplay how much fun the flying and shooting is in this game, it gives such an exhilarating and engaging feeling that's hard to find at this calibur. The game is recommendable on this aspect alone, the game is a prime example of a game that's just fun to play, you don't need any other motivation.Unfortunately, that's really all there is. The customization is limited, and a lot of the parts are kinda lack-luster in comparison to their counterparts. For example, I think the homing missiles, the cannon, the collision body, and bomb body are all utter garbage, their drawbacks all outweigh their benefits, and there are clearly better weapons. After for playing for just a few ours, the dominant strategy effect takes place and I see only three or four combinations worthy of my time. Randoming is fun as well, but a lot of the time you'll just get a back combination and die before you get anywhere really exciting. The names for each combination and mis-matched music tracks are really neat, but the novelty wears off as each match lasts just a few minutes. The missions are over in four or five hours and the SFMT, although gloriously hectic, gets a bit more frustrating than fun pretty quick. At the bottom line, the game sadly gets a little repetitive about four hours in.It's just that the game is so amazingly fun to play. Everything feels, looks, and sounds fantastic, it's a great experience. The price is a little steep for a game that gets a little old only four hours in, but if you don't mind fighting the same same seven enemy types over and over and over in rapid succession with stunted progression just for the sake of it, the game is simply and utterly fantastic.

Posted: November 21, 2015
A refreshing arcade game [KAMGUSTA's REVIEW]It's a nice arcade game (that escalates to "bullet hell" pretty quickly) where you play as a customizable World War II fighter and you have to destroy enemy planes, boats, battleships and a couple of bosses.The feature of this game is the "gravity" so you also have to account for it when flying.Too bad the game doesn't last long: after a couple of hours, as you unlock all the fighter's parts (weapons, body and engine... and not so many as the game description says), there is not much left to do.You can try to finish all the "missions", but some are ridiculous hard and the gameplay will just be the same. Again and again.A missed gem.Best played with KeyboardRecommended Buy Price < 5$Score 7/10

Posted: April 6, 2015
												Luftrausers is a nice little arcade shooter. It's good at what it does, and doesn't pretend to be anything more than that. There's no multiplayer, no additional maps or levels, no extended story or plot. Just fly around and shoot as much stuff as you can until you inevitably die.The various upgrades to your weapon, body, and engine types have meaningful differences on gameplay and strategy. There are enough combinations - and incentives to try them - that the upgrade system extended my playtime longer than I expected. I found it to be a pretty difficult game, and it took a while for me to get acclimated to the control scheme, but I had fun with it. Easily worth the price of admission.

												An arcade shooter with simple graphics and butt loads of fun.Dance through the air while playing with your engine and making incredibly satisfying turns and kills.With your first few runs being only seconds long this game will get you as soon you get the hang of it.Unlock new parts for your plane which will change the way you play completely. Posted: September 23, 2014
												You are a fighter pilot in a WW2-esque, sci-fi setting. The gameplay is that of a bullet-hell shooter, but instead of facing one direction like space invaders, you're constantly flying against gravity, and swooping over the water to get a shot at ships. What makes this game so compelling is the tight controls. There is no story, so don't look for one. Kill stuff, dodge bullets, and find the weapon/body/thrust system that works best for you.My favourite is combining the armoured body with a super thruster back (that reduces turning ability when thrusting), and the massive flak cannon attachment on the front. Everything dies right away, but I don't.

												Only two game-modes, both survival style, but the controls gameplay music and art are polished to perfection and there is a great depth of content in the ship customization; each different part involves a different and viable playstyle. Missions, progression and unlockables are executed very well: you won't have to grind for parts, but you won't have everything dumped on you at once, and the harder missions are challenging without being frustrating.It's a bit like Altitude, but in well-polished fast-paced shmup form. Far prettier too.

Posted: September 20, 2014
												Overall - 9/10Simple shootem up game that rewards players with new plane parts (Weapon/Hull/Engine) once objectives are met.Controlls are tight but very difficult to master.  The more you kill the harder it gets.  Great music in this game that changes as you switch out plane parts.

Posted: September 20, 2014
												Not a bad game, very interesting take on the bullet heaven genre. For starters, you're not limited by moving in one direction. You can fly through the sky freely, shooting at whatever you'd like. Another unique thing is recovery by cease fire. It might sound simple to stop shooting and heal, but it's much more difficult to do so when you're surrounded by enemies. Customization is fun, building your own war-machine, each combination with it's own name. Over all the game is very fun.

Posted: September 24, 2014
												Luftrausers is a really great game, but for the price of $10, I was expecting a little more. Don't get me wrong, I thoroughly enjoyed this game, but this is the kind of game I would spend $3 on in the app store. The controls are a little fiddly but you get used to it over time. Posted: September 19, 2014
